Built in 1860, under the rule of Sikander Jehan Begum, one of the most liberated women in the history of Bhopal who worked towards progression of the city by building several monuments, roads and bridges, this mosque stands as a testament to her incredible efforts and off-course to the glorious chapter of Bhopal‚Äôs history when it was led by women rulers. reviews.reviewText: I had the pleasure of visiting Moti Masjid in Bhopal, and it was an absolutely wonderful experience! The mosque is a beautiful example of Mughal architecture, with its intricate details and stunning marble work that truly leaves you in awe. The peaceful ambiance inside made it a perfect spot for reflection and tranquility. The surroundings are well-maintained, and the mosque itself stands as a testament to the rich cultural and historical heritage of Bhopal. Whether you're a history enthusiast or simply someone looking for a serene place, Moti Masjid is definitely worth a visit. Highly recommended!

Moti Masjid is a very beautifully built mosque. After going here, I felt that this is a very old mosque. People were offering Namaaz here. At that time, a lot of people were also coming here, so I could not click pictures properly. But this mosque is very beautiful. If you are here, then you must go here to visit. But you go here and the architecture here is very beautifully designed.

Moti Masjid in Bhopal is a stunning mosque that showcases the city's rich history and architecture. Built by Sikander Jehan Begum of Bhopal in 1860, this mosque is a significant historical landmark and a must-visit attraction in Bhopal.

The mosque's architecture is inspired by the famous Jama Masjid in Delhi, featuring a beautiful white marble facade with two small cupolas on top. The two dark red towers on either side of the primary structure add to the mosque's charm.

Moti Masjid have its peaceful atmosphere, making it an ideal spot for prayer and reflection. The mosque can be visited between 6 AM and 7 PM, and a typical visit lasts around an hour.

Best Time to Visit: Early morning hours for a peaceful experience.

Overall, Moti Masjid is a beautiful and historic mosque that offers a serene atmosphere for prayer and reflection. It's a must-visit attraction in Bhopal, especially for those interested in history, architecture, and culture.

The architecture of the Moti Masjid in Bhopal has a striking resemblance to the architecture of the Jama Masjid in Delhi, except for the size. The Moti Masjid features a white marble facade with two small cupolas on the top. The two dark red towers on either side of the primary structure of the mosque are equally beautiful and fascinating." - Moti Masjid, Bhopal
Nice place

Bhopal is home to a number of mosques, including the Moti Masjid. The Moti Masjid may be smaller than some of the other magnificent and historically significant structures in the ‚Äòcity of mosques,‚Äô but its significance cannot be understated. It was constructed in 1860 by Sikander Jehan Begum, a descendant of Qudusiya Begum of Bhopal, and is one of India‚Äôs best-known historical landmarks.

This mosque in Bhopal looks a lot like Delhi‚Äôs Jama Masjid, except for one thing: it‚Äôs smaller. Two modest cupolas adorn the Moti Masjid‚Äôs white marble exterior. On each side of the main building are two stunning and interesting dark-red tower.
Very Antique and beautiful Masjid üòç

Moti Masjid, or the Pearl Mosque, stands as a testament to Bhopal's rich history and architectural splendor. This magnificent structure, built by Sikandar Begum in the 19th century, is more than just a place of worship; it's a symbol of the city's cultural heritage and a captivating destination for visitors.

The mosque's exterior is a breathtaking sight. Constructed from pristine white marble, its elegance is immediately striking. The intricate carvings and delicate details adorning the arches, domes, and minarets showcase the exquisite craftsmanship of the era. The mosque's design is a perfect example of symmetry and balance, offering a sense of serenity and grandeur.

Inside, the mosque exudes a sense of peace and tranquility. The spacious prayer hall can accommodate a large congregation, and the mihrab, which indicates the direction of Mecca, is beautifully adorned. The courtyard provides a serene space for reflection, surrounded by the mosque's beauty. The overall atmosphere is one of reverence and calm, making it a perfect place for spiritual contemplation.

Visiting Moti Masjid is a truly enriching experience. It's not just a religious site but also a significant historical landmark that reflects the city's unique identity. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast, a history buff, or simply seeking a moment of peace, Moti Masjid is a must-visit destination in Bhopal. It's a place where history, art, and spirituality converge, leaving a lasting impression on all who visit.

placeMetadata.name: Gohar Mahal

sources.snippet: Located on the bank of ‚ÄòUpper Lake‚Äô, ‚ÄòGohar Mahal‚Äô is yet another of the best places to see in Bhopal. Standing tall as a testimony to the cultural legacy of this city of Nawabs, it is actually a beautiful mansion built in the form of a palace, representing an excellent blend of Mughal and Hindu styles of architecture. This magnificent palace is named after the first woman ruler of Bhopal, Qudisiya Begum, also popularly known as Gohar Begum who was not only an efficient and unbiased head of the state but also a great patron of art and architecture.
sources.shortName: 16 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh

sources.snippet: Qudsia Begum chose this vantage point along the road that circles the Upper Lake, to build her first-ever castle between 1819 and 1837. It serves as a magnificent historical sentinel, bearing witness to the splendours of Bhopal's renowned royal families. It is a fusion of Hindu and Mughal architectural traditions, covering an area of approximately 4.65 acres.
sources.shortName: Best Places to Visit in Bhopal (2025) - Top Attractions

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Gohar Mahal, constructed in 1820 by Qudisiya Begum, the first Queen of Bhopal, is a stunning example of Mughal and Hindu architectural fusion. The palace features Diwan e Aam and Diwan e Khaas, as well as inner fountains that have retained their majestic look despite being destroyed over time. Situated on the bank of Upper Lake, this mansion stands as a testament to Bhopal's cultural legacy.
placeMetadata.address: VIP Road, Nakkar Khana, Peer Gate Area, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh 462001, India

placeMetadata.name: Rani Kamlapati Palace

sources.snippet: ‚ÄòRani Kamlapati Palace‚Äô was the official residence of this beautiful queen in Bhopal, who once ruled in the hearts of her subjects owing to her irresistible poise & grace and extraordinary talents. It is one of the most popular tourist attractions to visit in Bhopal. Built around 1680 on the banks of the ‚ÄòLower Lake‚Äô, the palace was a gift to the queen by her husband, Nizam Shah and it is said that she spent full moon nights floating on the lake adjoining the palace in a lotus shaped vessel.

placeMetadata.name: Van Vihar National Park

sources.snippet: Spread over an area of approximately 445 hectares, the Van Vihar National Park is one of the most popular national parks in Central India, established in the year 1979. Considered as one of the best places to visit in Bhopal, the park is located just adjacent to the ‚ÄòUpper Lake‚Äô and attracts loads of nature lovers, wildlife enthusiasts and nature photographers throughout the year.
sources.shortName: 16 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh

sources.snippet: The Pre Wedding Shoot Locations in Bhopal includes Van Vihar National Park, where couples can capture their Pre Wedding memories. Evergreen forests, calm lakes, and unique wildlife here would provide an awestruck backdrop for their romantic Pre Wedding photoshoot. The serene beauty of the park makes it the ideal location for all couples to show their love and affection.
sources.shortName: Top 7 Pre Wedding Shoot Locations In Bhopal

sources.snippet: At a distance of 8 km from Bhopal Junction, Van Vihar National Park is a national park located in the beautiful city of Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh. Situated on the banks of Upper Lake, it is one of the popular parks in Madhya Pradesh, and among the must-visit places as part of Bhopal Packages. Declared a national park in 1979, Van Vihar covers an area of about 4.45 sq.
sources.shortName: 26 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: Van Vihar is a National Park and a Zoological Space that operates under the guidelines of the Central Zoo Authority. It is located just adjacent to the Upper Lake in Bhopal, near Shymala Hills. One of the most important tourist places in Bhopal, The animals here are kept closest to their natural habitats, making it a haven for people who love nature.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to visit in Bhopal India 2024

sources.snippet: Van Vihar is an expansive National Park with a Bird Interpretation center and Zoo. It is located close to Upper Lake at Lake View Walk Path, Krishna Nagar, Shymala Hills, Bhopal, and is house to a large number of animals. It is known for its splendid landscape and comprises of serene forest cover, natural ponds with amazing and floral diversity.
sources.shortName: Best 30 Places To Visit In Bhopal (2025 Updated List)

sources.snippet: The Van Vihar National Park is a zoological park that is bordered by Upper Lake. The park is spread over 445 hectares and is home to several wild animals like tiger, lion, bear, hyena and herbivores like cheetal, sambhar, and blackbuck. The atmosphere of the park is filled with the constant chirping of numerous birds in the park.
sources.shortName: Best Places to Visit in Bhopal (2025) - Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Van Vihar National Park provides a special fusion of wildlife and scenic beauty for couples who enjoy the outdoors. With its abundance of greenery and diverse animal inhabitants, the park offers a serene backdrop for pre-wedding photos. The park is open from early morning until late at night, with a small entrance fee.
sources.shortName: Best Pre-Wedding Shoot Locations in Bhopal: Capture Your Love Story

sources.snippet: Amid Bhopal sits Van Vihar National Park, a beautiful oasis. This natural reserve's lush woods, winding pathways, and tranquil lake make it ideal for pre-wedding shoot locations in Bhopal. You may add the park's natural charm to your photos by incorporating deer and other animals.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Best Pre-Wedding Shoot Locations in Bhopal for 2025

sources.snippet: Located at the heart of the city, covering an area of 445.21 hectare of land, Van Vihar National Park is home to a wide range of birds and animals. Some of the wild animals found here include tiger, lion, leopard, sambar and chital. The park is home to over 200 species of birds.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places To Visit In Bhopal

sources.snippet: The national park of Bhopal would be a choice of only a few who prefer to get a shoot in a natural habitat. However, the results are likely to turn in your favour if you dare to choose this location for the Pre-Wedding Photoshoot.
sources.shortName: Top Locations for Pre-Wedding Shoot in Bhopal

sources.snippet: This park is located adjacent to the upper lake, which makes it more attractive and finer. This spot could give a different experience than others for photography as it offers a wide range of photography of nature and wildlife.
sources.shortName: Top Pre-Wedding Shoot Locations in Bhopal

sources.snippet: The park is draped in green and flaunts hundreds of species of plants and animals. The park segments animals in two categories i.e. captives and herbivores.
sources.shortName: Tourist Places & Top Things to Do in 2024

placeMetadata.description: Set along Upper Lake, Van Vihar National Park is home to grassy meadows, wetlands, and bamboo plants, along with tigers and spotted deer. Leopards and hyenas are highlights of the zoo, while a rescue centre focuses on sloth bears. There‚Äôs also a vulture conservation breeding centre, a butterfly park, and an area exhibiting tortoises, plus a museum shop, and a handful of food stalls and eateries.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled beside the Upper Lake, Van Vihar National Park spans about 445 hectares and is a renowned destination in Central India. Established in 1979, it features diverse habitats such as grassy meadows, wetlands, and bamboo groves that house various wildlife including tigers, spotted deer, leopards, and hyenas. The park also houses a rescue center for sloth bears and a vulture conservation breeding center.
placeMetadata.address: Shymala Hills, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, India

placeMetadata.name: Upper Lake

sources.snippet: One of the most significant and expansive lakes of Bhopal, Upper lake is commonly known as the Bhojtal or Bada Talab. It is located near the CM House, Bhopal, and is the oldest human-made lake in the country A boat club on the eastern side offers thrilling water sports such as parasailing, kayaking, canoeing, rafting, etc. Built across the Kolan river by King Bhoj in the 11th-century, it serves as the major source of water for the people of Bhopal.
sources.shortName: Best 30 Places To Visit In Bhopal (2025 Updated List)

sources.snippet: With majestic view up to the horizon, the Upper Lake, also known as Bhojtal, is one of the largest lakes which the people of Bhopal can visit in the region. The place offers an ideal outing for youngsters as well as elder ones who enjoy their walks on the lakeside to rejuvenate themselves. Youngsters can also enjoy various water adventures activities such as boating, kayaking, and canoeing.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagrammable Places in Bhopal

sources.snippet: At a distance of 7 km from Bhopal Junction, Upper Lake is an artificial lake situated in the heart of Bhopal in Madhya Pradesh. Locally known as 'Bada Talaab', it is the oldest man-made lake in Madhya Pradesh, and among the must include places in Bhopal Tour Packages. Bhopal holds several lakes hence the city is widely known as the city of lakes.
sources.shortName: 26 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: Upper Lake, prominently known as Bada Talab in Bhopal, is an exquisite pre-wedding shoot place in Bhopal. This huge fake lake is encircled by lavish plant life and offers harmony and unwinding. Heartfelt photographs are best taken promptly in the first part of the day or late evening time as the sun sets.

sources.snippet: The Upper Lake also known as Bhojtal will provide you with the best scenic beauty in the evening while the sun is going down. sources.snippet: The largest lake in Bhopal, Upper Lake, also known as Bhojtal, is a sight to behold, especially at dusk. The serene waters and verdant surroundings provide an ambiance that is ideal for romantic photographs. Easy access is provided, and there is plenty of parking close by.

sources.snippet: A beautiful man-made lake built in the 11th century, the Upper lake was constructed by Raja Bhoj to cure skin diseases that were otherwise incurable. Also known as Bhojtal, is a splendid spot with an attractive royal garden called Kamla Park in the vicinity.

sources.snippet: UPPER LAKE‚Äì One of the finest location of the city, lake is the perfect place to capture sunsets and sunrise in the best possible way. Also , it is the perfect place to shoot in any hour of the day. It is the best place for people who love water and peace.

placeMetadata.description: Beyond its sweeping views & wildlife, this expansive artificial lake features boat clubs & tours.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Upper Lake, also known as Bhojtal Lake, is a stunning 31 square kilometer artificial lake in Bhopal. Created over eleven centuries ago by Raja Bhoja, it offers breathtaking views and opportunities to observe wildlife. Visitors can enjoy boat clubs and tours on the pristine blue expanse with tiny islands. The lake is surrounded by hiking trails and the Van Vihar National Park, home to a rich variety of birds and animals.

reviews.reviewText:
Very beautiful place in Bhopal, we can say it's a identity of Bhopal,
You can walk peacefully arround lake in the evening and also enjoy beautiful sunset from boat.
Upper Lake is the most serene place in Bhopal. Perfect for peaceful moments and fun activities like boating. A must-visit for nature lovers!

Bhopal is also known as the city of lakes. Therefore, it is the top destination in the city for the visitors throughout the year. Raja Bhoj, the Parmara King, who ruled the Malwa empire during 1010 - 1055 CE, built this lake during his reign, who is also credited to establish this city which is now the capital of Madhya Pradesh. As a token of honour, his statue is also established in the lake. Apart from rich history, this lake is also an important water body not only for the residents of Bhopal for whom this is a water reservoir, but also ecologically for the environment due to which it has been included in the Ramsar list of Wetlands. One can often find people especially during sunrise and sunset, relaxing and enjoying the cool breeze and the view.

Bhopal is a city of lots of human made lakes and this one is the biggest of all. It's a perfect place to chill in the evening and there are lots of snacking and street food options available over here. You can also do the boating if you're keenly interested or can just skip. There is beautiful art present over here which is made out of e-waste don't forget to check that out as well.

Brilliant! One of the tourist attractions! There are more than 35 fish species in the lake‚Ä¶. The lake never goes dry and is rich in nature‚Ä¶. I just hopethe government maintain its richness and does not construct anything around the lake‚Ä¶

Bhopal, India is known as the "city of lakes".¬†It has many lakes, including:

Bhojtal:¬†Formerly known as Upper Lake, this large lake is a major source of drinking water for Bhopal residents.¬†It was built by the Hindu raja Bhoj in the 11th century.¬†The lake is 1,000 years old and is the oldest man-made lake in India.

Upper Bhopal Lake (Bada Talab):¬†Connected to the Lower Bhopal Lake by an aqueduct.

Lower Bhopal Lake (Chhota Talab):¬†Has a surface area of 1.29 square kilometers and an average depth of 6.2 meters.

placeMetadata.name: Darul-Uloom Taj-ul Masajid

sources.snippet: Located on the shores of pristine ‚ÄòMotia Talaab‚Äô, the ‚ÄòTaj-ul-Masjid‚Äô is one of the biggest tourist attractions in the Bhopal and needless to say, a significant site of religious tourism for Muslims who travel here from far off corners of the country and the world. Often referred to as ‚ÄòThe Crown of the Mosques‚Äô, ‚ÄòTaj-ul-Masjid‚Äô is one of the largest mosques in India with a capacity to house 175,000 people at a time. Its generous size and splendid design also make it one of the most distinguished mosques in the world.
sources.shortName: 16 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh

sources.snippet: The Taj Ul Masjid is an architectural masterpiece built between the years 1868 and 1901, and the construction was started by Sultan Shah Jahan Begum of Bhopal. Being arguably one of the largest mosques in India, the Taj Ul Masjid is every photographer‚Äôs delight as the huge structure offers a picture-perfect symmetry ideal for photography. On your visit to the grand mosque, feel the spirituality in the air as the red-stone structure leaves you spellbound with its grandeur and serenity.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagrammable Places in Bhopal

sources.snippet: At a distance of 4 km from Bhopal Junction, Taj-ul-Masajid, or Taj-ul-Masjid is a 19th-century mosque located at the heart of Bhopal city in Madhya Pradesh. It is one of the largest mosques in India, and among the must include places in Bhopal Trip. Literally means 'The Crown of Mosques', the Taj-ul-Masjid is one of the largest mosques in Asia.
sources.shortName: 26 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: Bhopal is famous for its wealth of cultural and architectural wonders. One architectural wonder that has captured many hearts is the Taj-ul Masajid, a grand mosque that reflects the city‚Äôs Islamic heritage. With towering minarets and detailed carvings, couples throng to get a perfect backdrop for their Pre Wedding shoot.
sources.shortName: Top 7 Pre Wedding Shoot Locations In Bhopal

sources.snippet: Taj-ul-Masajid ranks amongst the largest mosques in the continent of Asia as it covers a sprawling 23312 square feet of land. The minarets are 206 feet tall. The construction was begun by Sultan Shah Jahan, Bopal‚Äôs Begum but owing to want of funds, it was not completed during her reign.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places To Visit In Bhopal

sources.snippet: It is one of the most stunning mosques of India and a prominent landmark of the city. With pink fascia, white-domed minarets, and sky-touching soars, the mosque turns into a gorgeous attraction of Bhopal. This remarkable monument is used as a sacred school (Madarsa) during the day.
sources.shortName: 10 Popular Places to See in Bhopal: Bhopal Tourist Attractions

sources.snippet: 2 km from city center 14 out of 30 Places To Visit in Bhopal. One of the largest mosques in the country, Taj-Ul-Masjid has a stunning and elegant architecture. The enormous domes, a spectacular hallway and elegant minarets speak volumes about its architecture.

sources.snippet: The mosque‚Äôs construction was started under the rule of Sultan Shah Jehan Begum of Bhopal. The name literally translates to ‚ÄòCrown among mosques‚Äô and rightfully so with a humongous architecture of pink walls and white domes.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Taj-ul-Masajid, also known as the "Crown of Mosques," is a massive 19th-century red-stone mosque located in Bhopal, India. It boasts imposing minarets, white domes, and intricate carved arches that showcase the city's elegant architectural style. Despite facing construction setbacks throughout history, it was finally completed in 1985 through public donations.
placeMetadata.address: near GPO Office, Royal Market, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh 462001, India

reviews.reviewText:
A Sikh's Perspective: A Soulful Experience at Taj-ul-Masajid, Bhopal

As a Sikh and someone who deeply values spiritual architecture and interfaith harmony, visiting Taj-ul-Masajid in Bhopal was a moving and memorable experience. The name itself ‚Äî meaning "Crown of Mosques" ‚Äî is a fitting tribute to this majestic structure that stands tall not just in scale, but in grace, serenity, and historical importance.

The first thing that struck me was its grandeur and tranquility. One of the largest mosques in India, it rises proudly with its pink fa√ßade, massive domes, and soaring minarets ‚Äî a reminder of India's rich Islamic architectural heritage. The mosque isn't just a place of worship, it's a living monument that carries centuries of devotion, resilience, and artistry.

What stood out most to me was the warmth and openness of the people. I was greeted with respect and curiosity. There was no barrier of faith ‚Äî only shared reverence. It reminded me of the teachings of Guru Nanak Dev Ji, who emphasized "Na koi Hindu, na Musalman" ‚Äî that at the root of all spiritual paths is one universal truth and Creator.

Whether you're spiritual, a lover of history, or simply someone seeking peace ‚Äî I wholeheartedly recommend a visit to Taj-ul-Masajid. It's not just a mosque ‚Äî it's a celebration of faith, culture, and the diversity that defines India.

This mosque is a very beautiful mosque. After going here you will feel as if you have gone there many years ago. People go to the mosque here to offer prayers. There are very good people living here with whom I have talked. They gave me a lot of information about the mosque. They told me how this mosque was built, who built it, when it was built, so after coming here I felt very good going inside this mosque.

The construction of the Taj-ul-Masajid was started by¬†Nawab¬†Shah Jahan Begum¬†of Bhopal, in the newly built walled suburb of Shahjahanabad. The exact year when construction was started is unclear; Sharma estimated it to be 1871. The Bhopal-based journalist and the author of¬†Masajid-e-Bhopal¬†(transl.‚ÄâThe Mosques in Bhopal), Aarif Aziz stated the date as 1887.

After Shah Jahan Begum died in 1901, the mosque continued to be built by her daughter,¬†Sultan Jahan Begum, till the end of her lifetime. The structure was planned in the midst of three water bodies, namely: Munshi Hussain Talab; Noor Mahal Talab; and Motia Talab. Hamidullah Khan¬†helped construct one gate of the mosque on the suggestions of Shah Jahan Begum.

The construction work was later on led by Islamic scholar Imran Khan Nadwi, whose brother Salman Khan Nadwi, supervised the constructions. The construction was complete by 1958 at an expenditure of 20 million Indian rupees. The entrance of the mosque was renovated with motifs from 13th century Syrian mosques donated by the¬†Emir of Kuwait¬†in memory of his late wife.

The Taj-ul-Masajid largely takes inspiration from Mughal architecture. The mosque has a pink facade topped by two 18-storey high octagonal¬†minarets¬†with¬†marble¬†domes, an impressive main hallway with attractive pillars, and marble flooring resembling the likes of¬†Jama Masjid¬†in Delhi and the¬†Badshahi Mosque¬†of Lahore.¬†It has a courtyard with a large¬†ablution¬†tank in the centre. It has a double-storeyed gateway with four recessed archways and nine cusped multifold openings in the main prayer hall. The massive pillars in the hall hold 27 ceilings through squinted arches of which 16 ceilings are decorated with ornate petalled designs.

The mosque also features a¬†zenana, rare given that prayer from home was the norm for women at the time of the mosque's construction.

As mentioned, Taj ul masjid is the 3rd largest  musjid in the world, its look similar to Delhi jumamasjid. For spending  some time for family  its good place outside of the musjid.. inside of the musjid have good ambiance and good architecture... women's and gents are allowed inside the musjid, gents are only a alloewd inside the main prayer hall and womens are allowed special area for the prayers, all other tourist women's to be dressed in a good manner, like not allowed half tops, croptops, half gowns etc..

Taj ul Masajid is absolutely stunning ‚Äî one of the largest mosques in India and a true gem of Mughal architecture. The massive domes, elegant minarets, and intricate detailing reflect the grandeur of a bygone era. Peaceful, majestic, and deeply spiritual ‚Äî a must-visit in Bhopal!

Taj-ul-Masjid literally meaning Crown of Mosques is located in Bhopal. It is the largest mosque in India. The construction of the mosque is started by Nawab Shah Jahan Begum and continued by her daughter Sultan Jahan Begum after her death. The mosque seems to be inspired by Jama Masjid Delhi. It is big, and when I visited, I saw many Jamaats means gathering or we  an say gathering of people who travel from one place to another to seek knowledge and spread messages of Islam among the community. It is quite a quiet place but always busy with people offering Namaz or just Jamatis sitting there. It is one of the landmarks in Bhopal and must be visited during the Bhopal trip.
India's biggest Mosque. Very good and calm atmosphere. Must visit place.

Don't go...
Nice monument & easy to go.
But very bad behaviour to Tourists specially if you are Hindu.
I was wearing Churidar with dupatta & visited along with my husband, doing nothing wrong.
The gate person kept shouting n disrespecting us constantly. Attaching the picture in my review for which he constantly shouted on us. Whereas there many families (Muslim) roaming n making blogs or reels or eating including couples... If I were local from Bhopal, I would have definitely visited the nearest police station for the behaviour he did to me.
To Hindu people - Don't go. Just see from gate. I am not a anti Muslim person or believe in comm-fights... but these people have criminal & cheap mindset everywhere no exceptions in Masjid also...

placeMetadata.name: Rani Kamlapati Palace

sources.snippet: Taking you back to the history lane is the ancient Rani Kamlapati Palace, which overlooks the Upper Lake and the Lower Lake. Built in the 18th century, the palace situated in the heart of Kamala Park used to be a residence of Rani Kamlapati, and it speaks of the glorious past of Bhopal. Built by Raja Bhoj, the palace is situated in an interesting location that separates the two lakes of Bhopal, thus enabling scenic views for those who want to click pictures at the most amazing historical place in Madhya Pradesh and upload them on their social media profiles.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagrammable Places in Bhopal

sources.snippet: ‚ÄòRani Kamlapati Palace‚Äô was the official residence of this beautiful queen in Bhopal, who once ruled in the hearts of her subjects owing to her irresistible poise & grace and extraordinary talents. It is one of the most popular tourist attractions to visit in Bhopal. Built around 1680 on the banks of the ‚ÄòLower Lake‚Äô, the palace was a gift to the queen by her husband, Nizam Shah and it is said that she spent full moon nights floating on the lake adjoining the palace in a lotus shaped vessel.

The Tribal Museum in Bhopal is a truly fascinating and enriching place to spend your time, offering a deep insight into the vibrant and diverse tribal cultures of Madhya Pradesh. Located in the heart of the city, the museum is not just a display of artifacts but a lively and colorful representation of tribal life, traditions, and beliefs. As you walk through its creatively designed galleries, you are greeted with a wide array of tribal-style handicrafts, traditional tools, ornaments, paintings, and lifestyle exhibits that reflect the simplicity, ingenuity, and artistic brilliance of tribal communities.

Each section of the museum is carefully curated to represent different tribal groups, showcasing their unique way of life, architecture, and cultural identity. The life-size models of tribal houses, complete with murals and intricate detailing, give visitors a realistic experience of tribal living environments. The museum uses modern display techniques, ambient lighting, and storytelling elements to make the exhibits both engaging and educational.

It is a place where tradition meets creativity ‚Äî from intricately carved wooden art to symbolic paintings that narrate myths and folklore. Visiting the Tribal Museum is not only visually delightful but also intellectually rewarding, offering a chance to appreciate the richness of indigenous heritage that often goes unnoticed. Whether you are a history enthusiast, an art lover, or simply a curious traveler, the Tribal Museum is a place worth visiting. It provides a refreshing escape from the usual tourist spots and leaves you with a deeper understanding of India‚Äôs tribal roots.

The Madhya Pradesh Tribal Museum in Bhopal showcases the rich heritage of the state's indigenous tribal communities. Located in Shyamla Hills, the museum features six galleries, including the Tribal Life Gallery, Stories of Worship and Sacrifice Gallery, and Tribal Art Gallery.

*Key Features:*

- Interactive displays and vibrant art installations
- Reconstructions of tribal habitats and exhibits on tribal art, culture, and traditions
- Regular performances, workshops, and interactive games

*Visitor Information:*

- Timings: 12:00 PM to 8:00 PM (Tuesday to Sunday), closed on Mondays
- Entry Fee: Rs. 20 for Indians (verify), Rs. 100 for foreign nationals
- Photography Charges: Rs. 100 extra

*Planning Your Visit:*

- Best time to visit: October to March
- Duration of visit: 2-3 hours ideal
- Wheelchair accessible with parking available on site

It‚Äôs more like a well-designed theme park than a true cultural experience. Good for photos and a quick visit, but don‚Äôt expect real tribal atmosphere or original artifacts.

Sair Sapata, Bhopal is a popular tourist and entertainment spot located on the banks of Upper Lake (Bada Talaab) in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, India. It was inaugurated on September 29, 2011, and developed by the Madhya Pradesh State Tourism Development Corporation to promote tourism in the region.

Key Attractions:

Suspension Bridge: Inspired by the Lakshman Jhula in Rishikesh, this pedestrian bridge is 183.2 meters long and 3.6 meters wide. It connects Prempura and Sewania and is considered the first of its kind in India.

Children's Play Area: A 2-acre area with various play structures and fun zones for kids.

Toy Train: A small train that circles around the park, offering scenic views and fun for children.

Musical Fountain: A water show synchronized with music, best viewed during the evening.

placeMetadata.name: Lower Lake

sources.snippet: Also known as ‚ÄòBhojtal‚Äô, the ‚ÄòUpper Lake‚Äô is one of the top places to visit in Bhopal and definitely a great site to enjoy a wonderful picnic with your friends and family. Nearby the ‚ÄòUpper Lake‚Äô is the ‚ÄòChhota Talab‚Äô or the ‚ÄòLower Lake‚Äô and both the upper and lower lakes constitute the ‚ÄòBhoj Wetlands‚Äô. Besides being a popular tourist attraction, these lakes also have great religious, social and cultural sentiments of the locals attached to them; the lakes are an important source of water, catering to the daily needs of almost 40% of the residents of the city.
sources.shortName: 16 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh

sources.snippet: Bhopal is also called the City of Lakes, and one of the major contributors to this identity of the city is the Lower Lake. Also known as Chhota Talab, the Lower Lake is a popular hangout destination for youngsters in Bhopal, and scenes of people clicking pictures along the lakeside are a common sight here. Built in 1794, the lake has successfully ornamented the Instagram profiles of many people visiting it owing to its picturesqueness and serenity.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagrammable Places in Bhopal

sources.snippet: At a distance of 4 km from Bhopal Junction, Lower Lake is a man-made lake located in the city of Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh. Also called Chota Talaab, the Lower Lake was built in 1794 by Chote Khan, a minister of Nawab Hayat Muhammad Khan Bahadur to beautify the city.

reviews.reviewText:
The Lower Lake is located to the east of the Upper Lake. An earthen dam separates the two lakes. The two lakes are built in a terraced manner, the lowest level of the Upper Lake is just below the highest level of the Lower Lake.

The Lower Lake has an area (water spread) of 1.29¬†, and its catchment area is 9.6¬†km2. The lake receives subsurface seepage from the Upper Lake. In the 1850s, the maximum and minimum depths of the lake were 11.7 m and 6.16 m respectively.¬†As of 2011, the maximum depth was 10.7m.

The Lower Lake does not have any¬†fresh water¬†source; it receives seepage water from the¬†Upper Lake¬†and drainage from 28 sewage-filled¬†nullahs.¬†It drains into the Patra rivulet, which joins¬†Halali River, a small tributary of the¬†Betwa River.
The lake was built by creating in 1794 to beautify the city. The construction was commissioned by Chote Khan, a minister of¬†Nawab¬†Hayat Muhammad Khan Bahadur.A number of earlier wells were merged in this lake. The lower lake is beside a bridge named 'Pul Pukhta'. The lower lake has also been mentioned as "Pukhta-Pul Talao" in literature.
The Lower Lake suffers from pollution due to drainage from sewage-filled nullahs, lack of fresh water source and¬†commercial washing¬†of clothes. The entire lake is¬†eutrophic, and its water is not suitable for drinking.

Had a good and peaceful mindset.
I saw the lower lake from Neelam park. So I believe I saw the backside of the river. The lake was a bit dirty but it was nice to watch the flowing water.

Lover Lake in Bhopal is a serene haven nestled amidst nature's embrace. Surrounded by lush greenery, the lake offers a peaceful retreat for those seeking solace and tranquility. Its pristine waters reflect the azure sky, creating a mesmerizing vista that soothes the soul. Whether you're taking a leisurely stroll along its shores, enjoying a romantic boat ride, or simply basking in the beauty of its surroundings, Lover Lake exudes an undeniable charm.

Moti Masjid in Bhopal is a stunning mosque that showcases the city's rich history and architecture. Built by Sikander Jehan Begum of Bhopal in 1860, this mosque is a significant historical landmark and a must-visit attraction in Bhopal.

The mosque's architecture is inspired by the famous Jama Masjid in Delhi, featuring a beautiful white marble facade with two small cupolas on top. The two dark red towers on either side of the primary structure add to the mosque's charm.

Moti Masjid have its peaceful atmosphere, making it an ideal spot for prayer and reflection. The mosque can be visited between 6 AM and 7 PM, and a typical visit lasts around an hour.

Best Time to Visit: Early morning hours for a peaceful experience.

Overall, Moti Masjid is a beautiful and historic mosque that offers a serene atmosphere for prayer and reflection. It's a must-visit attraction in Bhopal, especially for those interested in history, architecture, and culture.

The architecture of the Moti Masjid in Bhopal has a striking resemblance to the architecture of the Jama Masjid in Delhi, except for the size. The Moti Masjid features a white marble facade with two small cupolas on the top. The two dark red towers on either side of the primary structure of the mosque are equally beautiful and fascinating." - Moti Masjid, Bhopal

Bhopal is home to a number of mosques, including the Moti Masjid. The Moti Masjid may be smaller than some of the other magnificent and historically significant structures in the ‚Äòcity of mosques,‚Äô but its significance cannot be understated. It was constructed in 1860 by Sikander Jehan Begum, a descendant of Qudusiya Begum of Bhopal, and is one of India‚Äôs best-known historical landmarks.

This mosque in Bhopal looks a lot like Delhi‚Äôs Jama Masjid, except for one thing: it‚Äôs smaller. Two modest cupolas adorn the Moti Masjid‚Äôs white marble exterior. On each side of the main building are two stunning and interesting dark-red tower.
Very Antique and beautiful Masjid üòç

Moti Masjid, or the Pearl Mosque, stands as a testament to Bhopal's rich history and architectural splendor. This magnificent structure, built by Sikandar Begum in the 19th century, is more than just a place of worship; it's a symbol of the city's cultural heritage and a captivating destination for visitors.

The mosque's exterior is a breathtaking sight. Constructed from pristine white marble, its elegance is immediately striking. The intricate carvings and delicate details adorning the arches, domes, and minarets showcase the exquisite craftsmanship of the era. The mosque's design is a perfect example of symmetry and balance, offering a sense of serenity and grandeur.

Inside, the mosque exudes a sense of peace and tranquility. The spacious prayer hall can accommodate a large congregation, and the mihrab, which indicates the direction of Mecca, is beautifully adorned. The courtyard provides a serene space for reflection, surrounded by the mosque's beauty. The overall atmosphere is one of reverence and calm, making it a perfect place for spiritual contemplation.

Visiting Moti Masjid is a truly enriching experience. It's not just a religious site but also a significant historical landmark that reflects the city's unique identity. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast, a history buff, or simply seeking a moment of peace, Moti Masjid is a must-visit destination in Bhopal. It's a place where history, art, and spirituality converge, leaving a lasting impression on all who visit.

A Truly Divine Experience at Birla Mandir, Bhopal

My visit to the Birla Mandir in Bhopal was an absolutely unforgettable experience, one that filled me with a profound sense of peace and wonder. Perched majestically on top of the Arera Hills, the temple is a beacon of serenity that stands tall against the city's skyline. The moment you begin the ascent towards the temple, you can feel a shift in the atmosphere, a quiet calm that prepares you for the tranquility that awaits.

The temple itself is a masterpiece of architecture. The beautiful sandstone and marble structure glows with a soft, warm light, creating a visually stunning sight against the backdrop of the sky. The craftsmanship is evident in every corner, from the gracefully carved pillars to the magnificent spire that reaches upwards. It is a place that is clearly maintained with a great deal of love and care. The entire complex is spotlessly clean, which adds immensely to the sacred and pristine feeling of the environment.

Walking into the main temple area, I was greeted by the beautiful idols of Goddess Lakshmi and Lord Vishnu. The spiritual energy within the sanctum is palpable, yet gentle and welcoming. It is not a crowded or overwhelming place, but rather a space where you can sit quietly, reflect, and feel a deep connection to the divine. The surrounding gardens are just as lovely, with manicured lawns and beautiful flowers that make for a pleasant stroll.

One of the most breathtaking aspects of visiting Birla Mandir is the panoramic view it offers of Bhopal. From this vantage point, you can see the entire city spread out below you, with the shimmering lakes creating a picturesque landscape. I spent a long time just soaking in this incredible view, feeling completely detached from the hustle and bustle of daily life. It is a view that truly soothes the soul.

The complex also houses the Birla Museum, which was an unexpected and delightful bonus. It contains a fascinating collection of sculptures and artifacts that offer a glimpse into the region's rich history. It adds another layer to the visit, combining spirituality with art and culture.

My time at Birla Mandir was a highlight of my trip to Bhopal. It is more than just a place of worship, it is a sanctuary of peace, a marvel of architecture, and a viewpoint that offers the most spectacular vistas of the city. I left feeling refreshed, spiritually uplifted, and with a lasting impression of its serene beauty. I would wholeheartedly recommend a visit to anyone traveling to Bhopal. It is an experience that will stay with you long after you have left.

placeMetadata.name: Birla Museum

sources.snippet: Bhopal is dotted with an endless number of museums and galleries showcasing the enriching history and past glory of this princely state of Madhya Pradesh. While ‚ÄòMuseum of Mankind‚Äô and ‚ÄòState Archaeological Museum‚Äô are the top two of such tourist attractions in Bhopal, there is yet another museum that is sure to leave you spellbound with its antique collection of objects and artefacts dating back to Paleolithic and Neolithic periods. One of its kind museums in Bhopal, set amidst serene environs of Arera Hills, the ‚ÄòBirla Museum‚Äô preserves a huge collection of rare tools and equipment used by the primitive men during the stone-age.
sources.shortName: 16 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh

sources.snippet: Established in 1971, Birla Museum has a wonderful collection of manuscripts, paintings and sculptures belonging to the period from 2nd century BC to 6th century AD. Primitive tools used in Paleolithic and Neolithic age are on exhibit here. The stone sculptures belonging to the period between 7th and 13th centuries are also on display.

sources.snippet: One of India's greatest anthropology museums Indira Gandhi Rashtriya Manav Sangrahylay offers a comprehensive and extremely interesting story of the evolution of man and Indian culture. spreads over a vast area on the Shyamla Hills in the city it is an only tribal habitat, which exhibits contemporary tribal cultures and real dwellings of typical tribal villages of Indian states in a unique manner. sources.shortName: Best 30 Places To Visit In Bhopal (2025 Updated List)

sources.snippet: At a distance of 1 km from Van Vihar National Park, and 9 km from Bhopal Junction, Indira Gandhi Rashtriya Manav Sangrahalaya is a unique museum located at Shyamala Hills in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh. Situated near Van Vihar, it is one of the largest and leading anthropological museums in India, and among the most visited tourist places in Bhopal. Also known as the National Museum of Mankind or Museum of Man, the Indira Gandhi Rashtriya Manav Sangrahalaya (IGRMS) was established in the year 1985.
sources.shortName: 26 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: South of the Upper Lake sprawls the Indira Gandhi Rashtriya Manav Sangrahalaya a.k.a. the National Museum of Man, the largest anthropological museum in India, and one of the biggest in Asia. On an undulating terrain of over 200 acres, one can see an open-air exhibition of human habitations. Life-size dwelling units of the tribal, coastal and Himalayan villages are built in traditional architectural styles using indigenous raw materials, housing different ethnographic objects.

A Living Tribute to India's Rich Heritage ‚Äî An Unforgettable Experience!

Indira Gandhi Manav Sangrahalaya (Museum of Mankind) in Bhopal is truly one of the most unique and enriching museums I have ever visited. Spread across a vast, scenic campus on Shyamla Hills, overlooking the beautiful Upper Lake, this museum isn‚Äôt just a collection of artifacts ‚Äî it‚Äôs a celebration of India‚Äôs incredible tribal, rural, and cultural diversity.

What sets this museum apart is its open-air layout. You don‚Äôt just see history in glass cases ‚Äî you walk through it. Life-size tribal huts, traditional dwellings, agricultural setups, and village scenes from different states and communities across India have been recreated with amazing authenticity. Each corner of the museum tells a story ‚Äî from the art and rituals to the lifestyle and survival methods of our indigenous communities.

The indoor galleries are just as impressive, showcasing rare photographs, folk art, musical instruments, ornaments, masks, and even spiritual beliefs of different tribes. Everything is well-labeled and explained in both Hindi and English, making it easy to understand and connect with.

It‚Äôs not just educational ‚Äî it‚Äôs a peaceful, soul-touching journey through India‚Äôs roots. Walking through the lush green paths, hearing the birds, and soaking in the tribal wisdom makes this place feel sacred.

The staff is helpful, the premises are clean and well-maintained, and there‚Äôs enough space for families to enjoy without crowds. I highly recommend this museum for students, researchers, history enthusiasts, photographers, and anyone who wants to experience the real India beyond textbooks.

Take your time when you visit ‚Äî you‚Äôll leave with a deeper appreciation for India‚Äôs cultural richness and the resilience of its people. A true national treasure! üáÆüá≥‚ú®

placeMetadata.address: 2nd floor, 53, J, Harshavardhan Nagar, Krishna Nagar, Shymala Hills, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh 462003, India

reviews.reviewText: It's a paradise for lovers of classical Indian music. The entire Bhavan showcases the work of various artists, featuring paintings of renowned figures, poetry, a library, and more. It's highly recommended for anyone visiting the city and looking for a serene, peaceful spot to relax and enjoy the view of the lake. The place charges ‚Çπ20 per person (for Indian) and it's worth every penny.

A must-visit cultural gem in Bhopal! Bharat Bhawan beautifully blends art, architecture, and nature. From the serene lake views to the inspiring art galleries, every corner reflects creativity and heritage. The open-air amphitheatre and museum spaces are truly unique. Perfect for photography, reflection, and soaking in Madhya Pradesh‚Äôs vibrant cultural spirit. Highly recommended for art lovers and peace seekers alike!

Beautifully designed cultural centre
Bharat Bhavan in Bhopal is an architectural masterpiece blending modern design with traditional Indian aesthetics. Designed by Charles Correa, it harmonizes with the natural landscape. As a vibrant cultural hub, it nurtures art, music, theatre, and literature, preserving India‚Äôs diverse heritage while offering an inspiring space for contemporary expression.

A museum and a convention centre designed by the famous architect Charles Correa. It is interesting how the building has almost no elevation from the entry road, preserving the beautiful views of the lake behind.
The place is rich with spaces like a permanent museum, a tribal art gallery, indoor and an outdoor auditorium, a library along with graphic or the lithography studio with both indoor and outdoor spaces.
You've got to be very lucky to be able to see it all in one visit. I visited it twice and was fortunate enough have an opportunity to meet one of the very senior artists there and get his insights on the Antarang (the auditorium), its design and evolution over time.

Legendary Architect Charles Correa designed this place !! And it's beautiful ‚ù§Ô∏è The flow of movement of a person in this place is amazing. It creates an illusion that the building meets the horizon and beautifully blends with Upper Lake or Bhojtal of Bhopal. This building represents why Bhopal is called the city of lakes.

~Peaceful Place with Garden and View of Upper Lake.
~Here you can see Tribal Artefact, Tribal and Famous Artist    painting from great personality.
~Less known and very less crowded.
~ Well Maintained and Clean place
~ Occasionally many cultural and traditional programs are held here.

Bharat Bhavan is a milti-art museum set up in 1982 by then Prime Minister IndiraGandhi.  It displays paintings of differnt artist,manuscript of writers, classical music, and also held performances related to Indian art and culture.

Art & Painting lovers - must go to place.
Amazing presentation of MP tribal Art & Cultures... I loved it.

Avoid going during some VIP or Politicians functions. Choose some less crowded & peaceful days.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Bhojpur Temple, also known as Bhojeshwar Temple, is a significant historical site located in the heart of India's popular archaeological area, Bhojpur. Built in the 11th century by Raja Bhoj as a tribute to Lord Shiva, this incomplete temple features a 7.5 feet high shiva linga and is often referred to as the 'Somnath of the East.' The temple attracts devotees and tourists from around the world.

placeMetadata.name: Regional Science Center

sources.snippet: At a distance of 7 km from Bhopal Junction, Regional Science Centre is a science center in the Shyamala Hills area of Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh. It is one of the Science Museums in India, and among the most important places to visit in Bhopal, especially those who are travelling with children. The Regional Science Center in Bhopal was inaugurated in 1995 by the then president of India late Shankar Dayal Sharma.
sources.shortName: 26 Best Places to Visit in Bhopal, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: Nestled atop Shyamla Hills in Bhopal, Regional Science Center is more than just a museum. It's a captivating journey into the world of science and technological wonder. Boasting over 300 enthralling exhibits, it attractively packages entertainment with education.

placeMetadata.description: Kid-friendly museum with a wide range of working models related to science & technology.

It offers an engaging and educational environment with over 250 interactive exhibits covering various scientific subjects such as mechanics, energy, sound, light, and the atmosphere. Visitors can participate in hands-on activities and attend science shows and demonstrations. The center provides a unique opportunity for couples to bond over shared interests in science and exploration while enjoying an enjoyable learning experience.

reviews.reviewText:
The Regional Science Museum in Bhopal is a treasure trove of interactive science exhibits that ignite curiosity and foster a love for learning in children. With engaging displays, hands-on activities, and 3D shows, the museum provides an immersive experience that makes complex concepts accessible and fun.
But that's not all - the museum's outdoor park is a thrilling extension, featuring scientific games, rides, and life-sized dinosaur sculptures that bring prehistoric wonders to life.
To fully enjoy the museum's vast offerings, plan for a full-day visit, as there's plenty to explore, play, and discover. From dinosaur fossils to space exploration, and from interactive exhibits to outdoor adventures, the Regional Science Museum is a must-visit destination for kids and families seeking to spark a passion for science, learning, and fun!

It's a great place to grab knowledge on Science, and how certain things perform. Usually Schools organizes visits here with the whole School, the staff, the kids present here so it becomes kinda chaotic. If you want a peaceful visit I would suggest to go on weekdays. Anyways, a great experience.

The Regional Museum of Natural History in Bhopal is an exceptional place for anyone interested in the natural world. Located in a serene environment, the museum offers a fascinating collection of exhibits that showcase the biodiversity of India, particularly the Central Indian region.

The museum is well-organized, with sections dedicated to various aspects of natural history, including geology, paleontology, and environmental conservation. The displays are informative and engaging, making it an excellent educational experience for visitors of all ages, especially students.

One of the highlights is the life-size models of animals and the detailed dioramas that bring to life different ecosystems. The staff is knowledgeable and helpful, always ready to provide insights or answer any questions.

Overall, RMNH Bhopal is a must-visit for nature enthusiasts and those looking to learn more about India's rich natural heritage. It‚Äôs a place where education meets curiosity, making it a rewarding experience for everyone who visits.

People‚Äôs Mall in Bhopal is a unique blend of entertainment, culture, and leisure. The standout feature is the collection of life-size replicas of world-famous monuments like the Taj Mahal, Eiffel Tower, and Statue of Liberty, offering great photo opportunities and a mini world tour experience.

The mall also houses a water park with attractions such as a swimming pool, wave pool, and various water rides, making it a fun spot for families. Additionally, there‚Äôs a multiplex cinema, gaming zones, and a variety of food outlets to cater to different tastes. Ôøº

However, some areas could benefit from better maintenance. Visitors have noted issues like cleanliness in restrooms and the need for more active retail outlets. Despite these, the overall experience remains enjoyable, especially for those looking to spend a day exploring diverse attractions in one place.

Tip: Visit during the evening to see the monument replicas beautifully illuminated.

"Kanha Fun City is an absolute blast and the perfect way to spend a weekend! The 5-star rating is well-deserved. The park offers a fantastic mix of water and amusement rides that cater to all ages, making it a great destination for both families and groups of friends.

The place had a lit soothing vibe, with potters market, art exhibition, music and cultural activities going on.

Gohar Mahal was built in a successful manner by Qudisiya Begum in 1820 on the banks of the Upper Lake in Bhopal. She is the first woman ruler of Bhopal. She is popularly known as Gohar Begum. In 1819, she successfully ascended the throne of the erstwhile princely state after her husband assassination. Today, the Mahal or Palace is not in good condition and is currently under renovation, and I hope it will become a good place to visit tourists in Bhopal.

I attended jashn e urdu festival here, it was of nice ambiance. Plenty of parking spack and finding washroom was quite tricky.

The other side you can find Indian tea house.

In itself is a very empty place, not that interesting in itself and there is no reason for you to go there. But it hosts a lot of events and festivals and workshops and that's the time that you go visit this place. Last time I was here I was attending a local artisans and organic food market and it was great. Gauhar Mahal is like a cultural spot in the city center. It is situated near the upper Lake and is easily accessible. It also has a lot of parking space.

Built in 1820 by Qudsia Begum, also known as Gohar begum established the structure reflecting the Indo-Islamic architecture throughout the Mahal. This palace represents the foundation of Begum and Women rule in the land of Bhopal. Presently, the whole place is under repairment. The old architecture is been damaged. The administration is taking necessary cautions to ensure to preserve such heritage. There are no waiting lines, a guide will help you to gain knowledge about the place as well. Photos and Videos are prohibited there. Good place to visit.
Old palace in decent shape generally rented out for functions. Nothing grand in scale and architecture but gives a glimpse of old Bhopal. Evening dusk hours are good for photography.

Gohar Begum became the first woman to sit on the throne of Bhopal in 1819.

The construction of this magnificent palace spanned over 13 years and was completed in 1884 at a cost of 3,000,000.

reviews.reviewText: The Taj Mahal Palace in Bhopal was built by Shah Jahan Begum. The palace is very beautiful from outside. The interior as heard is amazing. Since now the palace is being converted to a heritage hotel so the caretaker does not allow anybody inside the palace. There are cctv cameras all around outside just to keep a watch that no one enters into the palace. The property now has become a private property. The architecture elements of Islamic architecture is well portrayed in this building. Great was the vision of our historical rulers and their infinite knowledge and also the highness of the craftsmanship at that time period. Apart from Taj Mahal in Agra this is another Taj Mahal which is in Bhopal.

When I went to Taj Mahal Palace, it was closed, but I clicked some pictures outside it. Unfortunately, I could not go inside it. I wanted to go inside it because I wanted to see the full view from its top. But I was unlucky. When I went, this monument was closed. Whenever you go, do visit here. I have seen it in many videos and photographs. The city view from its top looks very good.

This place is the oldest place of bhopal, however closed now for public views but if you see from the lake side then you will realise that its so beautiful and photogenic place, once the home of maharaja of Bhopal.

The Taj Mahal of Bhopal, built in the late 19th century by Sultan Shah Jahan Begum, was once a grand palace showcasing Indo-Islamic and European styles. Located in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, it has suffered neglect over the years, with parts in ruins despite efforts for restoration. Once a symbol of regal opulence, it now stands as a reminder of fading heritage, needing urgent conservation. Recently it has been taken over by hotel company to build a heritage hotel

The Taj Mahal at Bhopal was built as the Begum's residence, at a cost of ‚Çπ 3,000,000. Its construction spanned over a period of 13 years, from 1871 to 1884.[1] It was one of the largest palaces of the world built at that time.

The building was originally named Raj Mahal ("royal palace"). The British Resident at Bhopal, highly impressed with the architecture, suggested that the palace be renamed the Taj Mahal, the Taj Mahal at Agra having been built by the Begum's namesake Shah Jahan. The begum accepted the suggestion and the palace was renamed to Taj Mahal.[3] The Begum is said to have ordered a three-year-long celebration called Jashn-e-Taj Mahal after the completion of the building.

After the partition of India in 1947, Nawab Hamidullah Khan allowed Sindhi refugees to stay in the palace. They stayed in Taj Mahal for around 4 years, before shifting to Bairagarh. The palace suffered some damage during this period.[1] After India's independence, some members of the royal family of Bhopal stayed at the palace, but gradually moved away, as they had no money for the repairs. By 2008, large parts of the palace complex had collapsed.

The palace was declared a state heritage monument by the Government of Madhya Pradesh in 2005 and the state archaeology department carried out restoration in parts. However, it was de-notified in 2011. Until 2013, the Taj Mahal was under the archives department. In 2014 the monument was handled over to the Madhya Pradesh tourism department.[4]

In 2017, a private builder from Indore, was handed over the property on lease to develop the sprawling 19th century structure into a 120-room heritage hotel. As of 2023 the work is yet to be started.

reviews.reviewText:
Manuabhan Tekri, also known as Mahaveer Giri, is a prominent hilltop destination in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, offering visitors a blend of spiritual significance and panoramic city views. Perched atop a hill, it houses a revered Jain temple, attracting devotees and tourists alike.

Access and Ropeway Experience

Visitors can reach the summit via a well-maintained ropeway system, operational daily from 10:00 AM to 6:30 PM, with a nominal fee of ‚Çπ50. The ropeway ride provides breathtaking aerial views of Bhopal, enhancing the overall experience.

Temple and Scenic Views

At the top, the Jain temple stands as a serene place for reflection and prayer. The hilltop offers a 360-degree panoramic view of Bhopal, making it an ideal spot for witnessing sunrises and sunsets. Visitors have described the experience as mesmerizing, especially during these times.

Visitor Feedback

Many visitors appreciate the tranquility and beauty of Manuabhan Tekri. One reviewer noted it as a "nice place" where one can see all of Bhopal city from the mountaintop, mentioning the availability of a ropeway and the presence of a Jain temple.

Practical Information

The site is accessible via the ropeway or by road, with ample parking facilities available. It is advisable to visit during the early morning or late afternoon to avoid midday heat and to capture the best views.

Conclusion

Manuabhan Tekri offers a harmonious blend of spirituality, adventure, and natural beauty, making it a must-visit destination for those exploring Bhopal.

Manubhan Ki Tekri is a Hilltop point that is accessible by road and cable car in Bhopal. From this place, you can watch almost the entire Bhopal from the top. Eatery, children rides are also set up there for enjoyment. People come here with friends and family for picnic or to spend leisure time. Mahaveer Giri Mahatirath,  a Jain Temple is also situated there.

On airport Road (near lalghati) this high hillock is a good picnic point for family. It has a beautiful Jain temple & good restaurant. Can visit this place either by ropeway or through own vehicle. However, the 1 km approach road to the top and parking is quite congested. Grand View of Bhopal city and landing/ takeoff of aeroplanes from the nearby airport is quite pleasing. it's a good place for 1-2 hours trip.

**Breathtaking Views from the Manuabhan Tekri

I recently visited this tekri  and was blown away by the stunning views of the city, especially at night. As the sun dipped below the horizon, the city transformed into a twinkling canvas of lights.

The panoramic view from the top was simply mesmerizing ‚Äì the glittering streetlights, the vibrant billboards, and the majestic buildings all blended together to create a breathtaking spectacle.

Whether you're a photography enthusiast, a romantic at heart, or just someone who appreciates the beauty of nature and urban landscapes, this tekri is a must-visit spot.

The only reason I didn't give it a full 5 stars is that the experience could be improved with better infrastructure and maintenance.
It is a beautiful place to visit in the evening which is located in Bhopal and from here the entire view of Bhopal can be seen and a Jain temple is also established here.

ops.insert: Set along Upper Lake, Van Vihar National Park is home to grassy meadows, wetlands, and bamboo plants, along with tigers and spotted deer. Leopards and hyenas are highlights of the zoo, while a rescue centre focuses on sloth bears. There‚Äôs also a vulture conservation breeding centre, a butterfly park, and an area exhibiting tortoises, plus a museum shop, and a handful of food stalls and eateries.
Beyond its sweeping views & wildlife, this expansive artificial lake features boat clubs & tours.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Bhopal, the capital city of Madhya Pradesh, is a treasure trove of stunning landscapes and rich history, making it a photographer's dream. From the majestic Taj-ul-Masajid, with its intricate red-stone architecture and striking white domes, to the serene waters of Upper Lake, this city offers a myriad of picturesque backdrops that capture the essence of India. Whether you're wandering through the vibrant streets or exploring the tranquil parks, Bhopal's unique blend of culture and nature provides endless opportunities for capturing unforgettable moments.

As you stroll through the city, don‚Äôt miss the chance to snap a photo at the Rani Kamlapati Palace, where 18th-century architecture meets breathtaking views of the lakes. The Moti Masjid, with its elegant white facade and red towers, is another must-see for any photography enthusiast. With hidden gems like the Bhojpur Temple and lively spots like Sair Sapata, Bhopal invites you to explore its beauty and share your journey through captivating images. So grab your camera and get ready to discover the best photo spots this enchanting city has to offer!

sources.snippet: Gohar Mahal:  Gohar Mahal was built in 1820 by Qudisiya Begum, who was a great admirer of art and architecture. It was in the year 1819, after the assassination of her husband, Qudisiya Begum shouldered the responsibility of the princely state of Bhopal. She scrapped the conventional idea that women should be behind the veil and started working on women empowerment.

sources.snippet: Gohar Mahal (palace), was built in 1820, by the first woman ruler of Bhopal, Gohar Aara Begum (queen) also known as Qudisiya Begum who ruled from 1819 to 1837, after the death of her husband in 1819. Gohar begum turned out to be India‚Äôs first women‚Äôs libber. When she took charge of the princely state, the strength of East India Company was increasing simultaneously.

reviews.reviewText:
A Sikh's Perspective: A Soulful Experience at Taj-ul-Masajid, Bhopal

As a Sikh and someone who deeply values spiritual architecture and interfaith harmony, visiting Taj-ul-Masajid in Bhopal was a moving and memorable experience. The name itself ‚Äî meaning "Crown of Mosques" ‚Äî is a fitting tribute to this majestic structure that stands tall not just in scale, but in grace, serenity, and historical importance.

The first thing that struck me was its grandeur and tranquility. One of the largest mosques in India, it rises proudly with its pink fa√ßade, massive domes, and soaring minarets ‚Äî a reminder of India's rich Islamic architectural heritage. The mosque isn't just a place of worship, it's a living monument that carries centuries of devotion, resilience, and artistry.

What stood out most to me was the warmth and openness of the people. I was greeted with respect and curiosity. There was no barrier of faith ‚Äî only shared reverence. It reminded me of the teachings of Guru Nanak Dev Ji, who emphasized "Na koi Hindu, na Musalman" ‚Äî that at the root of all spiritual paths is one universal truth and Creator.

Whether you're spiritual, a lover of history, or simply someone seeking peace ‚Äî I wholeheartedly recommend a visit to Taj-ul-Masajid. It's not just a mosque ‚Äî it's a celebration of faith, culture, and the diversity that defines India.

This mosque is a very beautiful mosque. After going here you will feel as if you have gone there many years ago. People go to the mosque here to offer prayers. There are very good people living here with whom I have talked. They gave me a lot of information about the mosque. They told me how this mosque was built, who built it, when it was built, so after coming here I felt very good going inside this mosque.

The construction of the Taj-ul-Masajid was started by¬†Nawab¬†Shah Jahan Begum¬†of Bhopal, in the newly built walled suburb of Shahjahanabad. The exact year when construction was started is unclear; Sharma estimated it to be 1871. The Bhopal-based journalist and the author of¬†Masajid-e-Bhopal¬†(transl.‚ÄâThe Mosques in Bhopal), Aarif Aziz stated the date as 1887.

After Shah Jahan Begum died in 1901, the mosque continued to be built by her daughter,¬†Sultan Jahan Begum, till the end of her lifetime. The structure was planned in the midst of three water bodies, namely: Munshi Hussain Talab; Noor Mahal Talab; and Motia Talab. Hamidullah Khan¬†helped construct one gate of the mosque on the suggestions of Shah Jahan Begum.

The construction work was later on led by Islamic scholar Imran Khan Nadwi, whose brother Salman Khan Nadwi, supervised the constructions. The construction was complete by 1958 at an expenditure of 20 million Indian rupees. The entrance of the mosque was renovated with motifs from 13th century Syrian mosques donated by the¬†Emir of Kuwait¬†in memory of his late wife.

The Taj-ul-Masajid largely takes inspiration from Mughal architecture. The mosque has a pink facade topped by two 18-storey high octagonal¬†minarets¬†with¬†marble¬†domes, an impressive main hallway with attractive pillars, and marble flooring resembling the likes of¬†Jama Masjid¬†in Delhi and the¬†Badshahi Mosque¬†of Lahore.¬†It has a courtyard with a large¬†ablution¬†tank in the centre. It has a double-storeyed gateway with four recessed archways and nine cusped multifold openings in the main prayer hall. The massive pillars in the hall hold 27 ceilings through squinted arches of which 16 ceilings are decorated with ornate petalled designs.

The mosque also features a¬†zenana, rare given that prayer from home was the norm for women at the time of the mosque's construction.

As mentioned, Taj ul masjid is the 3rd largest  musjid in the world, its look similar to Delhi jumamasjid. For spending  some time for family  its good place outside of the musjid.. inside of the musjid have good ambiance and good architecture... women's and gents are allowed inside the musjid, gents are only a alloewd inside the main prayer hall and womens are allowed special area for the prayers, all other tourist women's to be dressed in a good manner, like not allowed half tops, croptops, half gowns etc..

Taj ul Masajid is absolutely stunning ‚Äî one of the largest mosques in India and a true gem of Mughal architecture. The massive domes, elegant minarets, and intricate detailing reflect the grandeur of a bygone era. Peaceful, majestic, and deeply spiritual ‚Äî a must-visit in Bhopal!

Taj-ul-Masjid literally meaning Crown of Mosques is located in Bhopal. It is the largest mosque in India. The construction of the mosque is started by Nawab Shah Jahan Begum and continued by her daughter Sultan Jahan Begum after her death. The mosque seems to be inspired by Jama Masjid Delhi. It is big, and when I visited, I saw many Jamaats means gathering or we  an say gathering of people who travel from one place to another to seek knowledge and spread messages of Islam among the community. It is quite a quiet place but always busy with people offering Namaz or just Jamatis sitting there. It is one of the landmarks in Bhopal and must be visited during the Bhopal trip.
India's biggest Mosque. Very good and calm atmosphere. Must visit place.

Don't go...
Nice monument & easy to go.
But very bad behaviour to Tourists specially if you are Hindu.
I was wearing Churidar with dupatta & visited along with my husband, doing nothing wrong.
The gate person kept shouting n disrespecting us constantly. Attaching the picture in my review for which he constantly shouted on us. Whereas there many families (Muslim) roaming n making blogs or reels or eating including couples... If I were local from Bhopal, I would have definitely visited the nearest police station for the behaviour he did to me.
To Hindu people - Don't go. Just see from gate. I am not a anti Muslim person or believe in comm-fights... but these people have criminal & cheap mindset everywhere no exceptions in Masjid also...

reviews.reviewText: I had the pleasure of visiting Moti Masjid in Bhopal, and it was an absolutely wonderful experience! The mosque is a beautiful example of Mughal architecture, with its intricate details and stunning marble work that truly leaves you in awe. The peaceful ambiance inside made it a perfect spot for reflection and tranquility. The surroundings are well-maintained, and the mosque itself stands as a testament to the rich cultural and historical heritage of Bhopal. Whether you're a history enthusiast or simply someone looking for a serene place, Moti Masjid is definitely worth a visit. Highly recommended!

Moti Masjid is a very beautifully built mosque. After going here, I felt that this is a very old mosque. People were offering Namaaz here. At that time, a lot of people were also coming here, so I could not click pictures properly. But this mosque is very beautiful. If you are here, then you must go here to visit. But you go here and the architecture here is very beautifully designed.

Moti Masjid in Bhopal is a stunning mosque that showcases the city's rich history and architecture. Built by Sikander Jehan Begum of Bhopal in 1860, this mosque is a significant historical landmark and a must-visit attraction in Bhopal.

The mosque's architecture is inspired by the famous Jama Masjid in Delhi, featuring a beautiful white marble facade with two small cupolas on top. The two dark red towers on either side of the primary structure add to the mosque's charm.

Moti Masjid have its peaceful atmosphere, making it an ideal spot for prayer and reflection. The mosque can be visited between 6 AM and 7 PM, and a typical visit lasts around an hour.

Best Time to Visit: Early morning hours for a peaceful experience.

Overall, Moti Masjid is a beautiful and historic mosque that offers a serene atmosphere for prayer and reflection. It's a must-visit attraction in Bhopal, especially for those interested in history, architecture, and culture.

The architecture of the Moti Masjid in Bhopal has a striking resemblance to the architecture of the Jama Masjid in Delhi, except for the size. The Moti Masjid features a white marble facade with two small cupolas on the top. The two dark red towers on either side of the primary structure of the mosque are equally beautiful and fascinating." - Moti Masjid, Bhopal
Nice place

Bhopal is home to a number of mosques, including the Moti Masjid. The Moti Masjid may be smaller than some of the other magnificent and historically significant structures in the ‚Äòcity of mosques,‚Äô but its significance cannot be understated. It was constructed in 1860 by Sikander Jehan Begum, a descendant of Qudusiya Begum of Bhopal, and is one of India‚Äôs best-known historical landmarks.

This mosque in Bhopal looks a lot like Delhi‚Äôs Jama Masjid, except for one thing: it‚Äôs smaller. Two modest cupolas adorn the Moti Masjid‚Äôs white marble exterior. On each side of the main building are two stunning and interesting dark-red tower.
Very Antique and beautiful Masjid üòç

Moti Masjid, or the Pearl Mosque, stands as a testament to Bhopal's rich history and architectural splendor. This magnificent structure, built by Sikandar Begum in the 19th century, is more than just a place of worship; it's a symbol of the city's cultural heritage and a captivating destination for visitors.

The mosque's exterior is a breathtaking sight. Constructed from pristine white marble, its elegance is immediately striking. The intricate carvings and delicate details adorning the arches, domes, and minarets showcase the exquisite craftsmanship of the era. The mosque's design is a perfect example of symmetry and balance, offering a sense of serenity and grandeur.

Inside, the mosque exudes a sense of peace and tranquility. The spacious prayer hall can accommodate a large congregation, and the mihrab, which indicates the direction of Mecca, is beautifully adorned. The courtyard provides a serene space for reflection, surrounded by the mosque's beauty. The overall atmosphere is one of reverence and calm, making it a perfect place for spiritual contemplation.

Visiting Moti Masjid is a truly enriching experience. It's not just a religious site but also a significant historical landmark that reflects the city's unique identity. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast, a history buff, or simply seeking a moment of peace, Moti Masjid is a must-visit destination in Bhopal. It's a place where history, art, and spirituality converge, leaving a lasting impression on all who visit.
S R farm islam nagar bhopal
