reviews.reviewText:
This royal building is situated at the entrance to the Chowk area in the heart of the walled city. Shaukat Mahal is a 19th century palace which was designed by a Frenchman, said to be a descendent the Bourbon kings. It combines Indo-Saracenic and Rococo architectural styles. The exterior of the palace is also carved with exquisite floral patterns that give the Mahal a very eco-friendly appearance. The Shaukat Mahal is flanked by the Sadar Manzil which served as a Hall of Public Audience during the princely period. This brick-red building has an ostentatious appearance, and the gardens that surround the palace makes the Manzil look very pretty.
The aesthetical interest of the castle, finish with overwhelming utilization of white alabaster and highlighting a progression of complex triangular molded curves on its roof, was additionally upgraded by flawless outsides decorated with sensitive flower designs giving it an eco-accommodating appearance. Indeed, even following two centuries, the magnificence and wonder of this authentic landmark stays unmatched in the city. Sightseers going to the site are certain to be left totally speechless with its charming magnificence and aesthetic interest. When going by 'Shaukat Mahal', do travel to the colorful red block building 'Sadar Manzil' that encompasses the royal residence. The splendid red of 'Sadar Manzil' impeccably supplements the smooth white development of 'Shaukat Mahal' and the rich gardens here further add that touch of greenery to the postcard culminate setting of these two excellent structures. Numerous a times, exceptional qawwali programs are additionally sorted out in the patio nurseries amid nighttimes. The background of flawlessly lit 'Shaukat Mahal' gives that mysterious feel to the entire environment. In the event that you get a shot, do go to this melodic execution and absorb your souls the Nawabi spirits of Bhopal.
The service and atmosphere is superb and authentic, however the food can definitely be improved. Kudos for trying new cuisine. We tried the chicken mandi.

It is not worthwhile to visit this Mahal. It may be historical, but the location has been lost, and it is home of many people.¬† It is not a place to visit, and you will be disappointed if you do. Instead, there are two MAhals nearby, one of which is under renovation, and the other is GOUHAR MAHAL. Its infrastructure has been dismantled and is no longer maintained by anyone. It feels more like a home than a Mahal or an old house. I was very disappointed to put this on my list of places to visit. As a result, it is not necessary to pay a visit.

One of the few Restaurants that give the authentic taste which is the branch of Delhi Aslam Chicken and to maintain that same quality and taste is to hats off.. While you Visit so do order Aslam Butter Chicken it's amazing + tasty & to go with Chicken Biryaani which quite tasty and impressive do recommend code for discount.

An almost 200-year old monument, which is still occupied by residents, in spite of almost being in ruins.
It is believed to have been constructed sometimes in the beginning of the 19th century as a wedding gift to Sikander Jehan Begum, the first full-fledged female ruler of Bhopal.
I was unable to visit inside, only viewed it from outside. It is indeed a majestic monument, and in several parts one can imagine it's foregone splendour.
Today a very good hotel operates on the premises.

Very poorly maintained historical Palace by the government of Madhya pradesh. I think the government of MP is not giving a little focus on the condition of Historical palaces the well known Shaukat mahal is a live Example. Once a beautiful and huge heritage building is in the worst condition now you can't even get Inside of the Shaukat Mahal due to it's worst condition.

There is grass all over the building, the building looks like a haunted place of b grade bollywood horror movies. Very poor and bad side of Madhya Pradesh Government can be seen here so sad to look at the Heritage Shaukat Mahal in such a awful condition.

Shaukat Mahal is one of the most beautiful buildings in Bhopal which has a distinct architecture - a blend of Indo-Islamic and European styles.

The roof of the building is adorned with a series of complicated triangular-shaped arches and the exteriors have beautiful patterns, showing artistic brilliance.

Its renovation is in progress.

Shaukat Mahal is a 19th century architect of Nawab of Bhopal and is situated in the old Bhopal near Peer gate. The building is under maintenance. This is one of the prestigious building and beautiful architect of Bhopal.

sources.snippet: During this period, Gohar begum sanctioned the enforcement of Jama Masjid (mosque) and also donated a large sum of money for the construction of the railway station. This marked the onset of an era of women rulers in Bhopal where political power rested with the Begums who were extremely liberal and had a modern outlook, contributing immensely to the city‚Äôs heritage.

sources.snippet: Jama Masjid of Bhopal is a fine-looking mosque constructed by Qudisiya Begum in 1837. The most renowned feature of this fresh-looking monument is the two imposing minarets that are evidently visible to bare eyes even from a long distance. This architecture represents the great art and dexterity of Islamic culture.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Bhojeshwar Mahadev Temple, located in the rural village of Bhojpur just outside of the city of Bhopal, is a well-known Hindu temple that dates back to at least the 10th or 11th century. The temple is unfinished, and its architecture and construction remain a mystery due to unknown reasons. Despite this lack of completion, the temple remains an important part of Hindu culture and tradition in the area.

reviews.reviewText: Amazing place. Administration has listened to the public and they cleaned this place. This place is at a unique location. The temple is an architectural marvel. One of the best places to visit in Bhopal! The temple is known for its massive Shiva Lingam and ancient architecture. Surrounded by natural beauty, it offers peace and a spiritual vibe. A perfect spot for history lovers, devotees, and nature seekers alike. Highly recommended for a serene getaway.

Visiting the Bhojeshwar Temple in Bhojpur, Madhya Pradesh, is like stepping back in time. Though incomplete, this ancient marvel exudes grandeur and serenity. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple houses an awe-inspiring 7.5-foot high lingam in its sanctum ‚Äî one of the tallest in India. The sheer scale and architectural brilliance are enough to leave anyone spellbound.

Believed to have been constructed in the 11th century during the reign of the Paramara king Bhoja, the temple stands as a powerful testament to the vision and craftsmanship of that era. Despite its unfinished state, the Bhojeshwar Temple remains spiritually enriching and historically significant.

Whether you're a history lover, a devotee, or simply seeking peace in a scenic setting, this temple offers a unique and humbling experience. A must-visit gem in the heart of Madhya Pradesh!

Bhojeshwar Mahadev Temple (‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞) is a historic and incomplete Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located in Bhojpur, near Bhopal, in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh.

Key Facts:

Commissioned by: King Bhoja of the Paramara dynasty (11th century CE)

Main Deity: Shiva (as a huge lingam)

Notable Feature:

The Shiva lingam here is among the tallest in India‚Äîabout 18 feet (5.5 meters) in height and 7.5 feet (2.3 meters) in diameter.

The temple is famous for its unfinished architecture, with many construction plans and marks still visible at the site.

Bhojeshwar Temple in Bhojpur, built by Raja Bhoj in the 11th century, is dedicated to Lord Shiva. It features a massive 18 ft high and 7.5 ft wide Shivling, carved from a single stone‚Äîone of the biggest in India. Though unfinished, the temple‚Äôs grand structure and peaceful surroundings make it a must-visit near Bhopal.

Bhojeshwar Mandir, located in Bhojpur near Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, is an unfinished 11th-century Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. It was commissioned by the legendary King Bhoja of the Paramara dynasty.
Key Highlights:
Massive Shiva Linga: The temple houses one of the largest Shiva Lingas in India ‚Äî about 7.5 feet high and 17.8 feet in circumference, carved from a single rock.
Unique Architecture: Though incomplete, the temple displays impressive stonework, with huge sandstone blocks and finely carved pillars.
Unfinished Structure: Construction seems to have stopped suddenly, and the reasons remain unknown. Nearby quarries and unfinished carvings offer clues to the ancient building techniques.
Sacred and Scenic: Set on a hilltop overlooking the Betwa River, the site is both spiritually significant and scenically beautiful.

placeMetadata.name: Upper Lake

sources.snippet: The largest and the oldest of these lakes, supplies the city with water ‚Äì the Upper lake, commonly known as ‚ÄòBara Talab‚Äô (Hindi for Big Lake), constitutes the thousand year old heritage of the city. Holding this lake is the equally ancient dam ‚Äì King Bhoja‚Äôs Dam, a reminder that Bhopal‚Äôs origins lay in a far-sighted environmental management that has stood the test of time. In the heart of the city today, lie many such silent documents of the history of Bhopal ‚Äì many of them in a ruined, unattended and uncared-for state.
sources.shortName: City with a past ‚Äì an account of the built heritage of Bhopal

sources.snippet: The two main lakes are the Upper Lake (Bara Talab) and the lower lake (Chhota Talab). The upper lake makes up the 1000 years old heritage of Bhopal and is an important element in shaping the city‚Äôs architecture.

placeMetadata.description: Beyond its sweeping views & wildlife, this expansive artificial lake features boat clubs & tours.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Upper Lake, also known as Bhojtal Lake, is a stunning 31 square kilometer artificial lake in Bhopal. Created over eleven centuries ago by Raja Bhoja, it offers breathtaking views and opportunities to observe wildlife. Visitors can enjoy boat clubs and tours on the pristine blue expanse with tiny islands. The lake is surrounded by hiking trails and the Van Vihar National Park, home to a rich variety of birds and animals.

Upper Lake is the most serene place in Bhopal. Perfect for peaceful moments and fun activities like boating. A must-visit for nature lovers!

Bhopal is also known as the city of lakes. Therefore, it is the top destination in the city for the visitors throughout the year. Raja Bhoj, the Parmara King, who ruled the Malwa empire during 1010 - 1055 CE, built this lake during his reign, who is also credited to establish this city which is now the capital of Madhya Pradesh. As a token of honour, his statue is also established in the lake. Apart from rich history, this lake is also an important water body not only for the residents of Bhopal for whom this is a water reservoir, but also ecologically for the environment due to which it has been included in the Ramsar list of Wetlands. One can often find people especially during sunrise and sunset, relaxing and enjoying the cool breeze and the view.

Bhopal is a city of lots of human made lakes and this one is the biggest of all. It's a perfect place to chill in the evening and there are lots of snacking and street food options available over here. You can also do the boating if you're keenly interested or can just skip. There is beautiful art present over here which is made out of e-waste don't forget to check that out as well.

Upper Bhopal Lake (Bada Talab):¬†Connected to the Lower Bhopal Lake by an aqueduct.

placeMetadata.name: Edward Museum Building now Central Library, Bhopal

sources.snippet: Central Library (Edward Museum Building):  The building was built in 1908, by Nawab Sultan Jahan Begum, a beautiful red stone building, with Teak wood and oak furniture, huge cupboards filed with thousands rare books, written by the Begums of Bhopal. The Begum had built Edward Museum Building to display the various gifts and artifacts presented to the royal family. This museum had been inaugurated in 1909 by the Viceroy of India, Lord Minto but had to close down due to lack of maintenance during the royal reign itself.

sources.snippet: Additions to the public buildings in this period included the Revenue Courts, the Court of Justice, Minto Hall, Civil Club, Hamidia Kutubh Khana (Library), Imperial Bank and the Edward Museum. Along with these, a number of residential bungalows were built on picturesque locations. The buildings of this period are mostly European in character with high ceilings and raised plinths.

(Translated by Google) Built in 1877 by Nawab Shahjahan Begum, who was as great a builder as her namesake, the Mughal emperor Shahjahan, the palace was designed as a pleasure pavilion. Opposite Motiva Talia, one of three spring-fed lakes that were created at the same time to collect runoff from the neighboring Idaho hills, Benazir Palace is now over 130 years old and, by all accounts, was rebuilt about thirty years ago Should have been treated as heritage property. But, no, it was never considered as a heritage property and very strangely it was in the possession of the local medical college. How it came into the possession of the college, which is only 57 years old, baffles everyone. Worse, the college, exercising its property rights, leased it to NCC, which in turn, reportedly leased it to Prakash Jha's film company for a sum of Rs 5 lakh. It is a strange case of a lessee sub-leasing his rights over a property which is essentially public property. Apparently, the district administration was aware of this transaction, as Prakash Jha was given permission to shoot in the Palace premises by the local District Collector.

It was only when the media and Bhopal Nagarik Manch created an uproar in this matter that the government realized the mistake. The medical college had no idea that what it had was a heritage property. It seems that he had no hesitation in selling Benazir Maidan to NCC for a nominal sum as he was engaged in construction work at a nearby site. When Prakash Jha arrived, the tenant must have thought it was a God-given opportunity to earn some money. Thankfully, after a major discussion in The Times of India, all the irregularities in the handling of the case were removed. The government granted additional time to prepare a notification designating the palace as a "protected monument". A small delegation of Bhopal Nagarik Manch got the opportunity to see it while meeting the Archaeological Commissioner. Notification would have been issued by now.

It is not just Benazir Palace where the state government has failed to protect Bhopal's heritage structures. Over the years, many such structures, including several gates of the former walled city of Shahjahanabad, have been allowed to be occupied by unauthorized people. Worse, the Taj Mahal Palace, which was lovingly built by Shahjahan Begum and which later earned praise from the British high and mighty, was most unwisely used as a refuge for migrants after independence from Pakistan. Permission was given. This one thoughtless act of the then provincial government almost destroyed the palace. Similarly, the Gol Ghar, which was once an aviary for the Begum and has now been mercifully restored and renovated, was also handed over to the police one after another, without taking care of it. The case of Benazir Palace is no different. It was allowed to be used as a college. Due to a fire in its laboratory, some parts of it were badly damaged.

According to the report, it is not clear who owns the palace. However, now that the Archaeological Department is going to take it under its control, it is expected that it will be taken better care of. The Archaeological Commissioner has assured Citizen Forum that Prakash Jha's film will also be shot in the palace complex under the supervision of experts (possibly archaeologists).

Maintenance of heritage properties in Madhya Pradesh has gone haywire because the state government has not yet formed heritage conservation committees in many cities and towns. Such committees should be formed under the rules for conservation of heritage sites, buildings etc. In the absence of such committees, many heritage sites of historical and cultural importance have been lost due to lack of identity and identity. It's not too late yet; Perhaps even now the culture department can initiate this process and form such committees at least for those cities where many heritage structures and sites are located in or around them.
Mahatma Gandhi addressed a rally here in 1929.

placeMetadata.name: Minto Hall Rd

sources.snippet: Minto Hall (Old Vidhan Sabha):  The foundation stone for Minto Hall was laid on 12th November 1909. The fourth and the last begum of Bhopal ‚Äì Nawab Shah Jahan Begum conceived the very beautiful ‚ÄòMinto Hall‚Äô to felicitate Lord Minto, the then Viceroy of India. After India attained Independence in the year 1947 and formation of the state of Madhya Pradesh, it became a natural choice for the assembly hall for MP State Government.

sources.snippet: Additions to the public buildings in this period included the Revenue Courts, the Court of Justice, Minto Hall, Civil Club, Hamidia Kutubh Khana (Library), Imperial Bank and the Edward Museum. Along with these, a number of residential bungalows were built on picturesque locations. The buildings of this period are mostly European in character with high ceilings and raised plinths.

placeMetadata.name: Jama Masjid Bhopal

sources.snippet: The Charbagh style of planning with pilasters and floating columns personify Islamic architecture in Bhopal. Besides the bridges at the northern and eastern gates, five-storied octagonal minarets peep out to overview the architectural heritage of Bhopal. Columns divide the site in half, while around 32 balconies segregate the stories with a dome at the top.
sources.shortName: The architectural heritage of Bhopal - Top 10 places for architects.

placeMetadata.description: Known for its enormous size, this 1600s mosque has domes, minarets & a vast courtyard.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Jama Masjid in Bhopal is a large, important mosque built during the Nawab of Bhopal period. It is decorated with domes, minarets, and a vast courtyard and is one of the most beautiful mosques in India. It is well maintained and popular among tourists.
placeMetadata.address: Chowk Bazaar Rd, Jama Masjid, Ibrahimpura, Peer Gate Area, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh 462001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Jama Masjid is the second-largest mosque in Bhopal and also the pride of Bhopal.

This mosque is situated in a congested market area.

Most tourists come to visit this mosque for its beautiful classic Islamic architecture.

This mosque has three side entry doors you enter from anywhere.
Friday prayer at 1pm. No car parking facility available

One of best mosque in bhopal .Established during the reign of Qudsiya Begum in 1837, Jama Masjid in Bhopal is a masterpiece of Islamic architecture and a testament to the enduring spiritual legacy of the region.

A must visit. I went to the Jama masjid at night. There were hardly any people about. Being a non Muslim, I was not sure whether I could enter or not, so I asked an elderly gentleman who was exuding the mosque. He said I could go in & escorted me in himself.

The mosque was brilliantly lit from outside. I did i was the only visor & had the whole mosque to sit in tranquility or peace. I took a few moments to disk in the atmosphere of the place.

I would say this is among the more beautiful mosques in India & well maintained.

Jama Masjid in Bhopal was built by Qudsia Begum who had aslo built the famous Gauhar Mahal. The Begums ruled Bhopal and shows how women had the power to rule and build something which stands till today. The Begum were very wise. Their knowledge on Islamic architecture is well portrayed in the elements of the entire building. The place is mostly deserted apart from tourists travelling there. I request others to upload the correct pictures of the Masjid as few people have Added Taj ul Masajid pictures. Beware of the wrong pictures. I am sharing few pictures when i visited there.

Jummah Mubarak, I wish you and your family a blissful and blessed Jumma.

May Allah grant you mercy for the sake of this holy day! Jumma Mubarak!

All I wish that every Jummah prayer brings peace, joy, and forgiveness of Allah to all of your lives and strengthen the faith upon Him...üòá

placeMetadata.name: Lower Lake

sources.snippet: The two main lakes are the Upper Lake (Bara Talab) and the lower lake (Chhota Talab). The upper lake makes up the 1000 years old heritage of Bhopal and is an important element in shaping the city‚Äôs architecture.
sources.shortName: An Architectural Review of Location: Bhopal - RTF

placeMetadata.description: Laid-back lake with serene hill & sunset views known for pollution issues & no fresh water source.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Lower Lake, also known as Chhota Talab, is a serene and picturesque destination in Bhopal. It is adjacent to the Upper Lake and together they form the Bhoj Wetlands. The lake is surrounded by lush greenery and islands, offering couples a romantic setting for activities such as boating, birdwatching, and picnicking.
placeMetadata.address: Jahangirabad, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh

reviews.reviewText:
The Lower Lake is located to the east of the Upper Lake. An earthen dam separates the two lakes. The two lakes are built in a terraced manner, the lowest level of the Upper Lake is just below the highest level of the Lower Lake.

The Lower Lake has an area (water spread) of 1.29¬†, and its catchment area is 9.6¬†km2. The lake receives subsurface seepage from the Upper Lake. In the 1850s, the maximum and minimum depths of the lake were 11.7 m and 6.16 m respectively.¬†As of 2011, the maximum depth was 10.7m.

The Lower Lake does not have any¬†fresh water¬†source; it receives seepage water from the¬†Upper Lake¬†and drainage from 28 sewage-filled¬†nullahs.¬†It drains into the Patra rivulet, which joins¬†Halali River, a small tributary of the¬†Betwa River.
The lake was built by creating in 1794 to beautify the city. The construction was commissioned by Chote Khan, a minister of¬†Nawab¬†Hayat Muhammad Khan Bahadur.A number of earlier wells were merged in this lake. The lower lake is beside a bridge named 'Pul Pukhta'. The lower lake has also been mentioned as "Pukhta-Pul Talao" in literature.
The Lower Lake suffers from pollution due to drainage from sewage-filled nullahs, lack of fresh water source and¬†commercial washing¬†of clothes. The entire lake is¬†eutrophic, and its water is not suitable for drinking.

Had a good and peaceful mindset.
I saw the lower lake from Neelam park. So I believe I saw the backside of the river. The lake was a bit dirty but it was nice to watch the flowing water.

Lover Lake in Bhopal is a serene haven nestled amidst nature's embrace. Surrounded by lush greenery, the lake offers a peaceful retreat for those seeking solace and tranquility. Its pristine waters reflect the azure sky, creating a mesmerizing vista that soothes the soul. Whether you're taking a leisurely stroll along its shores, enjoying a romantic boat ride, or simply basking in the beauty of its surroundings, Lover Lake exudes an undeniable charm.

placeMetadata.name: Bharat Bhavan Bhopal

sources.snippet:
Architect: Charles Correa
Year: 1982
Style: Fusion of Modern and European Architecture
Area: 11000 m2
Concept: Ritualistic Pathway. This building is one of the few successful efforts to build a cultural and heritage centre all over India by the government of India. The site has a contour sloping down towards a lake.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to visit in Bhopal for the Travelling Architect - RTF

placeMetadata.description: Cultural space with galleries & an open-air theater, hosting art exhibits, performances & events.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Bharat Bhavan, located on J Swaminath Marg on Shamla Hills, is a cultural space inaugurated in 1982 by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. It serves as a hub for contemporary arts including dance, theater, film, painting and sculpture.
placeMetadata.address: 2nd floor, 53, J, Harshavardhan Nagar, Krishna Nagar, Shymala Hills, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh 462003, India

reviews.reviewText: It's a paradise for lovers of classical Indian music. The entire Bhavan showcases the work of various artists, featuring paintings of renowned figures, poetry, a library, and more. It's highly recommended for anyone visiting the city and looking for a serene, peaceful spot to relax and enjoy the view of the lake. The place charges ‚Çπ20 per person (for Indian) and it's worth every penny.

A must-visit cultural gem in Bhopal! Bharat Bhawan beautifully blends art, architecture, and nature. From the serene lake views to the inspiring art galleries, every corner reflects creativity and heritage. The open-air amphitheatre and museum spaces are truly unique. Perfect for photography, reflection, and soaking in Madhya Pradesh‚Äôs vibrant cultural spirit. Highly recommended for art lovers and peace seekers alike!

Beautifully designed cultural centre
Bharat Bhavan in Bhopal is an architectural masterpiece blending modern design with traditional Indian aesthetics. Designed by Charles Correa, it harmonizes with the natural landscape. As a vibrant cultural hub, it nurtures art, music, theatre, and literature, preserving India‚Äôs diverse heritage while offering an inspiring space for contemporary expression.

A museum and a convention centre designed by the famous architect Charles Correa. It is interesting how the building has almost no elevation from the entry road, preserving the beautiful views of the lake behind.
The place is rich with spaces like a permanent museum, a tribal art gallery, indoor and an outdoor auditorium, a library along with graphic or the lithography studio with both indoor and outdoor spaces.
You've got to be very lucky to be able to see it all in one visit. I visited it twice and was fortunate enough have an opportunity to meet one of the very senior artists there and get his insights on the Antarang (the auditorium), its design and evolution over time.

Legendary Architect Charles Correa designed this place !! And it's beautiful ‚ù§Ô∏è The flow of movement of a person in this place is amazing. It creates an illusion that the building meets the horizon and beautifully blends with Upper Lake or Bhojtal of Bhopal. This building represents why Bhopal is called the city of lakes.

Nawab Sikandarjahan Begum, the 8th ruler of Bhopal, granted the permission to construct a Catholic Church.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: St. Francis of Assisi Cathedral Church stands as a historic gem in Bhopal, reflecting the city's rich colonial past. Constructed with the approval of Nawab Sikandarjahan Begum, this church was built to serve the British officers stationed nearby during their rule. Its establishment in 1824 marked it as one of the oldest Catholic churches in the region, showcasing beautiful architecture and a welcoming atmosphere for worshippers.
placeMetadata.address: 6CXC+M93, inside St Francis School Campus, C.L.Colony, Jahangirabad, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh 462008, India

reviews.reviewText:
This church is one of the oldest buildings in Bhopal city. During the princely era, the British military cantonment was in Sehore. Bhopal's first church was built for the British officers stationed there.

Madam Isabella Elizabeth Bourbon commonly known as Dulhan Sahiba, an honorific title to the bride of Balthazar Bourbon-I, alias Shazad Masih Prime Minister of Bhopal, during the reign of Nawab Nazir-ullah Mohammad Khan Ruler of Bhopal, Purchased in 1852 AD.

Nawab Sikandar Jahan Begum, the 8th ruler of Bhopal state, gave permission to build this Catholic chh, which was built under the supervision of Father Bernard Pistoia in 1873 AD during the time of Bathazar Borbon alias Shahzad Masih, the successor of Salvador Borbon.

Princess Isabella Bourbon got the construction of the church building commenced on the 4th October 1873, and that could be erected and completed in 1875.

The establishment of a Catholic Church at Bhopal dates from the late half of the 19th century, an epoch episode of history, when Christianity dawned at the horizon of a Muslim conservative principality of Bhopal, in the heart of Central India.

Finally on 24th of October 1875, the Rev. Dr. Paul Josi, Cap Vicar Apostolic of Agra, assisted by Father Raphael and Father Norbert, solemnly blessed the church amidst a large gathering comprising of Princess Isabella Bourbon her relatives, dignitaries from the Begum's palace and the Bhopal Christians. This Church was renovated in 1963 by the annual grant from the State and it was accorded the status of a Cathedral.

Within the main building of this celebrated church, right opposite to the altar final resting place means graves of¬† Isabella Bourbon Founder of this church and her relatives and family members side by side.

The successors of Prince Balthazar Bourbon-I and Princess Isabella Elizabeth Bourbon still live in Bhopal and are a part and participant of this church and Bhopal diocese.

It's the first Catholic Church dedicated to the St. Francis is a popular place of worship among the Roman Catholic Christians. It's located in Jahangirabad, Bhopal which was the British Cantonment area and was built by Nawab Jahangir Mohammed Khan.

Today on the eve of Christmas I went to the church. There was not much of a crowd located in a busy commercial street.
The church was beautifully decorated, pictures of which I have shared.

THIS CHARCHA IS ONE OF THE OLDEST BUILDINGS OF BHOPAL CITY IN THE STATE PERIOD THE BRITISH MILITARY CANTONMENT WAS AT SEHORE.THE FIRST CHARCHA OF BHOPAL WAS CONSTRUCTED FOR THE BRITISH OFFICERS SATATIONED THERE THE 8TH RULER OF BHOPAL STATE .NAWAB SIKANDARJEHAN BEGHUM GRANTED THE PERMISSION FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE CATHOLIC CHARCH. WHICH WAS CONTRACTED UNDER THE SUPERSIVION OF FATHER BRANARD PISTOIAAT THE TIME OF BATHAZAR BORBANALIAS SHAHJAD MASIH,THE SUCCESSIR OF SALVADOR BORBAN IN1824 A.D. ANNUAL STATE GRANT WAS ALSO GIVEN TO IT.IT WAS RESNOVATED IN 1963 A.D.AND ACCOREDED THE STATUS OF CATHEORAL THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT CATHOLIC CHARCH.
Sunday mass time please..?

reviews.reviewText:
As a part of a Design and Build project for a Manufacturing set-up which was for a foreign MNC in Bhopal, we approached K Atelier for complete design and interiors for the new full fledged office facility for our client.
It was an old building was in a very bad shape and not in use for a few years, part of it was a lab and store. It was very challenging since the existing layout was not fit for an office. To our disadvantage the client did kot give us enough freedom to break down existing walls and some fixtures to save on the cost.
But still, to our delight and surprise K Atelier managed to come up with so many creative ways to match the design intent with the least of demolition activity. We still were hesitant about the end result considering the control factors and boundations set by the client.

But as it approached the last stages of interiors the unfolding of the final look and feel was quite astounding not just to us but the client as well. The blending of interiors, colors, fixtures, furniture and especially the lighting was very soothing and carried a rich modern look. Part of it was a high-tech quality lab and a sample room which also merged with the theme with ease.
A good design is not only how it looks but also how it functions, which could be experienced walking in this new office facility and exploring its features.
We would love to work with this firm again in the future and would strongly recommend their services, not only based on the result but also how smooth and professional their approach has been to work with!
All the best wishes to the Founder and the team!

The Taj Mahal of Bhopal, built in the late 19th century by Sultan Shah Jahan Begum, was once a grand palace showcasing Indo-Islamic and European styles. Located in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, it has suffered neglect over the years, with parts in ruins despite efforts for restoration. Once a symbol of regal opulence, it now stands as a reminder of fading heritage, needing urgent conservation. Recently it has been taken over by hotel company to build a heritage hotel

The Taj Mahal at Bhopal was built as the Begum's residence, at a cost of ‚Çπ 3,000,000. Its construction spanned over a period of 13 years, from 1871 to 1884.[1] It was one of the largest palaces of the world built at that time.

The building was originally named Raj Mahal ("royal palace"). The British Resident at Bhopal, highly impressed with the architecture, suggested that the palace be renamed the Taj Mahal, the Taj Mahal at Agra having been built by the Begum's namesake Shah Jahan. The begum accepted the suggestion and the palace was renamed to Taj Mahal.[3] The Begum is said to have ordered a three-year-long celebration called Jashn-e-Taj Mahal after the completion of the building.

After the partition of India in 1947, Nawab Hamidullah Khan allowed Sindhi refugees to stay in the palace. They stayed in Taj Mahal for around 4 years, before shifting to Bairagarh. The palace suffered some damage during this period.[1] After India's independence, some members of the royal family of Bhopal stayed at the palace, but gradually moved away, as they had no money for the repairs. By 2008, large parts of the palace complex had collapsed.

The palace was declared a state heritage monument by the Government of Madhya Pradesh in 2005 and the state archaeology department carried out restoration in parts. However, it was de-notified in 2011. Until 2013, the Taj Mahal was under the archives department. In 2014 the monument was handled over to the Madhya Pradesh tourism department.[4]

In 2017, a private builder from Indore, was handed over the property on lease to develop the sprawling 19th century structure into a 120-room heritage hotel. As of 2023 the work is yet to be started.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: When in Bhopal, a visit to the Lakshmi Narayan Temple, also known as Birla Mandir, is a must. This architectural marvel is one of 18 temples built by the esteemed Birla family and stands proudly on the Arera Hills. The temple's sandy-yellow exterior offers stunning views of the surrounding lakes and landscapes, especially when complemented by the nearby Birla Museum.

sources.snippet: Dhai Seedi ki Masjid:  ‚ÄòDhai Seedi ki Masjid‚Äô literally means the mosque of two and a half steps. The first mosque of Bhopal, the Dhai Seedi Ki Masjid, was also built in the year 1723, so that the fort guards could perform namaaz (prayers). One of the smallest mosques in Asia it is located right across Taj-Ul-Masajid.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Dhai Seedhi Ki Masjid, also known as the mosque of two and a half steps, is a historic site located in Bhopal. Built in 1723 by Nawab Dost Mohammad Khan, it stands atop the remains of a guard-tower of the Fatehgarh Fort. This small mosque holds the distinction of being Bhopal's first mosque and is considered to be the smallest mosque in Asia.
placeMetadata.address: 796R+22Q, Medical College Campus, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh 462001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Dhai sedhi Masjid is also known as india's one of the smallest mosques.

This mosque is more than 300 years old.

On my visit to Bhopal I was keen to visit this mosque but when I found the main gate of the mosque was closed.

I was sad for a while but suddenly something chuckled in my mind I went upstairs and knocked on the door after a few minutes Iman sahab came and asked what happened.

I salam him and said I can from very far to visit this mosque please open the door and Alhmdulillah he opens the door and gets the opportunity.

If you ever visit and find the door is closed just knock the door for a while.

The Dhai Seedi Ki Masjid, or "the mosque of the two and a half steps," is a small mosque in Bhopal, India.The mosque is known for its simple architecture, which includes only two and a half stairs leading to the worship space. It's believed to be Bhopal's first mosque and one of the oldest in the city.

The first guard at Fatehgarh Fort used to pay Namaz. The history of this mosque is also three hundred years old. It is said that when Noor Mohammad Khan and his brother-in-law Dost Mohammad Khan arrived in India from Terah, Afghanistan, the reign of Queen Kamlavati took place in Bhopal. Kamlavati husband was poisoned by his nephews. The queen was very upset about this and wanted revenge. Announced a reward of a reward for the person who takes revenge. The friend Mohammed Khan completed this work. As a result, the Queen gave fifty thousand rupees to the cash and the remaining fifty thousand for the then Fatehgarh, the annual Lagaan was ten thousand rupees, she gave it to her friend Muhammad Khan. In later times, the friend Mohammad Khan built the fort of Fatehgarh in this place. The cornerstone of this fort was laid by Qazim Mohammed Moazzam Sahab. Mosque in the western direction of the fort was delivered to the tower. In the year 1716, the 'two-storey mosque' became the first mosque in Bhopal.

The Dhai Seedhi Ki Masjid, literally meaning "The mosque of the two and a half step" is a small mosque atop the remains of a guard-tower (bastion) of the Fatehgarh Fort, Bhopal. This mosque was built by Nawab Dost Mohammad Khan in 1716.

'Dhai Seedhi Ki Masjid' has the credit of being the first mosque of Bhopal. Apart from this, it is also the smallest mosque in Asia. The naming of the mosque has a story of its own. At the time of its construction, everything has been made two and a half. The stairs are two and a half, the number of rooms in the place where this mosque is situated is also two and a half. Apart from this, the number of stairs in the way from which one used to come here earlier, is only two and a half.

The history of this mosque is three hundred years old. The watchmen used to offer prayers in this mosque built on a dome made for vigilance on the ramparts of Fatah Gad fort, located on the banks of Bade Talab in the old city. In the Fatehgarh fort, earlier the soldiers guarding used to offer Namaz.

The two and a half step mosque is in the upper part of the bastion of the fort of Fatehgarh near Gandhi Medical College, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh. This mosque was built by friend Mohammad Khan. Built in plain and simple architecture, this mosque has only two and a half steps to reach the place of worship, hence it is called 'two and a half step mosque'. This mosque is believed to be the first mosque in Bhopal.

Bhopal‚Äôs oldest and teeniest mosque (early 18th century; 16 sq metres inside) stands on top of an old fortification tower next to the Gandhi Medical College. The tower was part of Fatehgarh, the fort built in the 1720s by Dost Mohammed Khan.

Dhai Seedi Ki Masjid is in one of the watchtowers. It is the oldest mosque in Bhopal city, initially built as a makeshift mosque during the construction of the Fatehgarh fort started by Dost Mohammad Khan. It was built so that the guards deployed at Fatehgarh Fort could perform Namaaz.

Dhai seedhi mosque is believed to be only of two and a half steps worship place and believed to be one of the oldest mosque of bhopal. It is part of the erstwhile fatehgarh fort and located in front of gandhi medical college. New construction around the steps, the original mosque is not seen from the outside.

reviews.reviewText:
The Eklavya Foundation Building in Bhopal provides an exemplary experience owing to its staff's exceptional behavior, high-quality accommodation, and delectable canteen food. The staff exude warmth and professionalism, making visitors feel welcome and attended to, creating a pleasant atmosphere within the facility.

The accommodation facilities are commendable, boasting comfortable and well-maintained spaces that prioritize the comfort and convenience of guests. The attention to detail in providing a restful environment adds to the overall positive experience.

Furthermore, the canteen's food offerings stand out with their diverse menu and delicious dishes. The emphasis on providing healthy yet tasty meals enhances the overall satisfaction of the visitors and staff alike.

Architecturally, the Eklavya Foundation Building stands as a testament to sustainable design principles. Its innovative architectural design incorporates eco-friendly materials, efficient energy systems, and thoughtful utilization of natural light and ventilation. The building's layout optimizes space while minimizing its environmental impact, promoting sustainability in its construction and operation.

Additionally, the incorporation of green spaces, such as rooftop gardens or surrounding landscapes, contributes to a refreshing ambiance and promotes environmental conservation.

Overall, the Eklavya Foundation Building not only excels in its staff's courteousness, excellent accommodation, and delightful cuisine but also serves as a prime example of sustainable architecture, showcasing a commitment to environmental responsibility and creating an inspiring, eco-conscious space for all who visit.

It was my dream to visit this place, and it was even better than what I could have imagined. It is extremely quiet and peaceful to visit this place. They believe in the idea of self serving. They gave us extremely healthy food majority of which came from there kitchen garden. They are extremely good hosts.
I would highly recommend this place, and I would myself want to keep visiting it whenever I get the chance.

placeMetadata.name: Central library

sources.snippet: Central Library (Edward Museum Building):  The building was built in 1908, by Nawab Sultan Jahan Begum, a beautiful red stone building, with Teak wood and oak furniture, huge cupboards filed with thousands rare books, written by the Begums of Bhopal. The Begum had built Edward Museum Building to display the various gifts and artifacts presented to the royal family. This museum had been inaugurated in 1909 by the Viceroy of India, Lord Minto but had to close down due to lack of maintenance during the royal reign itself.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Bhopal, the capital city of Madhya Pradesh, is a treasure trove of architectural wonders that beautifully blend history and modernity. From the intricate designs of Indo-Islamic palaces to contemporary structures that push the boundaries of creativity, this city offers a unique glimpse into the evolution of architecture over the centuries. One cannot help but be captivated by the stunning Moti Masjid, with its striking white facade and red towers, or the majestic Taj-Ul-Masajid, which stands as one of the largest mosques in India. Each building tells a story, reflecting the rich cultural heritage and artistic prowess of the region.

As you wander through Bhopal, you'll discover a vibrant mix of renowned architectural firms and hidden gems that showcase innovative designs and sustainable practices. The passion for architecture is palpable, with firms like Vinyaasa Architecture and Design and ArcMax Architects leading the way in creating spaces that resonate with the community. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast or simply curious about the city's offerings, Bhopal invites you to explore its diverse architectural landscape and uncover the stories behind each remarkable structure.
